summary: Paul Merson reignited his public feud with Andros Townsend after criticizing his late substitution in a 0-0 draw against Burnley. Merson had previously questioned Townsend's inclusion in the England squad in a Sky Sports column. However, Townsend proved Merson wrong by scoring a goal in a 1-1 friendly draw against Italy. Despite this, Merson maintained his stance, citing Townsend's previous performance at Manchester United as a reason for his initial criticism. The two exchanged jabs on Twitter, but any animosity seemed to have subsided after Townsend's goal. However, Merson couldn't resist another dig at Townsend following a Tottenham draw.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's Yoshinori Muto, a 22-year-old Japan international forward. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, would join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if the transfer is completed. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has earned 11 caps for Japan and scored one goal. A £4million deal has been suggested, but Muto has not yet decided to join Chelsea. Yokohama Rubber, a Japanese company, has signed a £200million sponsorship deal with Chelsea.

A large-scale study suggests that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research, published in Pediatrics, compared the weight and height of over 12,000 two-year-olds with antibiotic prescription records. Children who had taken antibiotics as infants were particularly likely to be overweight, with repeated prescriptions raising the odds further. The study did not prove causation, but suggested that antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic by killing gut bacteria that would normally consume some of the food we eat. The researchers emphasized the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy. The study also noted that boys were more affected by antibiotic-induced weight gain and were slightly taller than those not given antibiotics. The findings add to concerns about the over-prescription of antibiotics, which could lead to common infections becoming harder to treat.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover while taking his position during the Changing of the Guard, an event caught on camera by a tourist. The guard, wearing full regalia, lost his footing and fell, causing some embarrassment. The incident occurred in front of a large crowd of tourists. The guard quickly recovered and continued his duties. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The epic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and depicted an African-American slave's story, is being remade by A&E networks for a 2016 release. The new version, co-executive produced by LeVar Burton, who played the original Kunta Kinte, aims to be more original and contemporary, drawing closely from Alex Haley's novel. It will be a collaborative effort between A&E, Lifetime, and History Channel, with input from scholars in African and African-American history to ensure authenticity. The remake will reach a new generation of viewers, including those who have seen Barack Obama become the first African-American president and the film "12 Years a Slave" win an Oscar.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, is being investigated by police for claims that palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy in 1978. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, said he was accosted by senior staff members on his first day working at Clarence House. He reported the incident to Clarence House, but his complaint was ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide has denied involvement, and the Royal Household has pledged to cooperate with the police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood. The Meeks shared a sonogram of their unborn child at the end of the video, which was made to inform distant loved ones about the pregnancy. The video's success was unexpected for the couple.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The light gray ensemble, originally slate blue-gray, was worn in key scenes and is part of a collection that belonged to James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios employee. The dress, along with over 150 other items from the film, was auctioned at Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, California. Other notable auction items included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes ($30,000).

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after being dangled over the edge by his parents, resulting in minor injuries. He was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. The boy was taken to the hospital with minor bruises and bumps, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The cheetahs did not approach the boy during the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, originally used to enforce the 30mph speed limit, has been angled at a house after being non-functional for over two years. The West Midlands decommissioned around 300 old technology cameras in 2013, replacing them with mobile units, motorway fixed cameras, and patrolling traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the misdirected camera and plans to investigate, possibly removing it. The camera in question won't be part of the upcoming digital technology pilot. The house owners couldn't comment on the situation.

Usain Bolt will participate in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas as part of the Jamaican team on May 2 and 3. The six-time Olympic gold medallist is fit and ready to compete, aiming to continue Jamaica's successful tradition in relays. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed delight at Bolt's participation, anticipating'sprint magic' on the track. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon. Bolt is committed to making his country proud while wearing Jamaican colours.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending an El Clasico match. Barcelona won the basketball game 85-80 against Real Madrid. In football, Neymar scored for Brazil against Chile and led his team to a 1-0 victory. Real Madrid is still leading their Euro League division over Barcelona. Neymar and Barcelona will face Celta Vigo in La Liga. Neymar's sister Rafaella attended the basketball game. Neymar was targeted by Gary Medel during the football match against Chile.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with 8,480 migrants rescued from Friday to Monday. A reported shipwreck with 550 people aboard has left 400 potentially missing, but the Italian coast guard has not confirmed the incident. In the first three months of 2015, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy, and at least 480 have died crossing the Mediterranean this year due to bad weather, overcrowded boats, and abandonment by captains and crews.

The passage discusses Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger's thoughts on Alexis Sanchez choosing Arsenal over Liverpool, and his impact on the team. Sanchez, who was courted by several top clubs, chose Arsenal for an undisclosed reason, but has since made a significant impact, scoring 19 goals in the season. Wenger also mentions Liverpool's interest in Sanchez during Luis Suarez's transfer negotiations. Wenger also downplays rumors of a potential summer transfer move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome, aiming to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner will challenge the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis. Tickets for the event will be available from April 19, and the attempt will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins hopes to set a mark that will last for some time and inspire others to challenge themselves.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, found her match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup challenging, describing it as an 'eye-opener' for her claycourt season preparation. Despite winning the singles match 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, Williams and her partner Alison Riske lost the doubles match 6-0, 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the US team's relegation to World Group II. Williams acknowledged the need to adjust her game for claycourts, while US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the importance of hard work to return to the elite nations next year. Williams's victory over Errani marked her 8-0 career record against the Italian.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them for eight years before moving to Porto in 2009. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, has expressed their desire to have Falcao return, stating that the doors are open. Falcao has struggled with his performance at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals this season. However, he has been in good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games. During his time with River Plate, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a pop star and X Factor finalist, has become the face of the dry shampoo brand Batiste for their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. The 19-year-old singer will be featured in various hairstyles in the campaign, which was orchestrated by the MILES agency. Henderson has expressed her excitement about working with Batiste, a brand she uses regularly. This partnership marks Henderson's first brand endorsement.

The family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are upset over a billboard featuring Torres. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, has been deemed disrespectful by Siler's loved ones, with one family friend stating it felt like a thank you for killing Aaron. The police association claims the billboard was meant to express gratitude for community support following recent incidents. Siler was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant, and the shooting occurred after a vehicle and foot pursuit. The investigation into the shooting is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border. Three militants were also killed, with the group Jaish al Adal claiming responsibility. The militants reportedly crossed into Iran from Pakistan, and Iranian officials have asked Pakistani authorities to catch the survivors. Jaish al Adal is an anti-Iranian group that targets Shiites and aims to reduce Iranian influence in Pakistan. The Pakistani government has condemned the attack and promised to bring any militants who entered Pakistan to justice.

The Japanese government's top military official has stated that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object (UFO). Responding to a query from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani said that the ASDF scrambles fighter jets when it detects unidentified flying objects that could violate Japan's airspace, but has never found any objects believed to have come from outer space. Inoki, who has appeared in the U.S.-based WWE and is the founder of the New Japan Pro Wrestling organization, asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. The exchange follows a 2007 discussion by then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba on the legal implications of defending against an invasion from outer space.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after he broke a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China. Initially, he admitted to squatting on the toilet due to hygiene concerns, but later changed his story to sitting when questioned by the police. The incident is believed to be an accident, and authorities reminded people to use toilets as intended, for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom over a four-year period. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the girl found the camera in March. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims, including the 15-year-old, and had purchased the camera specifically for this purpose. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series features fathers in suits leaping energetically next to their po-faced daughters, capturing a humorous and odd contrast between the two. The images, part of a book titled "Daughter and Salary Man," showcase the fathers expressing their fun side and excitement through their jumps. The photos, taken in front of various Japanese landmarks, have garnered interest online for their unique and curious nature.

The passage discusses Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England cricket team after his dismissal as managing director of English cricket, Paul Downton. Pietersen, who was controversially axed in 2014, is now focusing on his performance with Surrey in the County Championship season. His participation in the Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval is seen as a step towards his possible reintegration into the England team. Pietersen's last international appearance was during the 2013-14 Ashes tour in Australia, where England suffered a whitewash series defeat.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time within a week due to a poor performance leading to a 2-0 loss against FC Botosani. This decision came after a brief reinstatement following an initial dismissal. Ze Maria, who had a stint as a player for Inter Milan and Parma and earned 25 caps for Brazil, was replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic. The club currently stands 16th in the league, six points away from safety. Ze Maria had taken over as Ceahlaul's third coach of the season in January, replacing Florin Marin.

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes Falcao may regret his failed loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Falcao struggled to perform at United after a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals in the season. United has the option to make the transfer permanent for £46million, but it is unlikely due to his performance. Dirar suggests Falcao might have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have participated in the Champions League.

The New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. The robbery occurred on Saturday when the man demanded cash from the owner's daughter, threw the cash register on the ground, and escaped with the till drawer containing up to $1,500. There were no weapons involved, but the offender remains at large. Police are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for alleged sexual misconduct with two 15-year-old students. The first arrest occurred on March 19, after she admitted to an inappropriate relationship with one student, which included kissing and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail. The second arrest followed shortly after, when another student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail for the second time and released after posting a $50,000 bail. She was suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave by school officials.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its mouth has been viewed over 500,000 times. The incident occurred when a dog went to investigate the crocodile, resulting in its death. The crocodile, a common sight in the area, held on to the dog for hours. The video sparked reactions of horror on social media.

Steve Bruce is confident Hull City can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, with six games remaining. Hull City had a strong start to the season but have only achieved six wins, with Bruce now hoping for eight or nine to survive. Injuries to key players have impacted the team's performance. Hull City currently sits two points clear of the relegation zone. Southampton moved up to fifth in the table with the win. Ronald Koeman, the Southampton manager, faced an issue with Sadio Mane attempting to take a penalty meant for James Ward-Prowse. Koeman plans to address the situation with his team.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from teaching for two years after he was found to have allowed students to change their SATs answers at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. Guffick also altered some answers himself. The Department for Education annulled the school's SATs results for the year following an investigation. Guffick admitted to the allegations and expressed regret for his actions. The decision to ban him was upheld by the National College for Teaching and Leadership, stating that no changes should be made to exam scripts outside test conditions. Guffick has 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United goalkeeper, has a fulfilling personal life despite limited playtime. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri, with Albanian roots, in a beach wedding in Mauritius in 2019. The couple, who have a son, have been together since 2012. Lindegaard often shares his personal life on Instagram, where Beqiri also posts her modeling work. Despite his struggles at United, including being third-choice goalkeeper and linked to a move to FC Midtjylland, Lindegaard enjoys a happy family life.

The 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, with estimates of $300,000 to $600,000. A Sotheby's employee was the only bidder, offering $260,000. The letters were purchased by Reggie Jackson, a Yankee Hall of Famer, after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson bought the letters for an undisclosed amount and wanted a new generation to own them. The letters were installed in 1976 and taken down in 2008. A New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed the recent misconduct of Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, who were caught using a shisha pipe and inhaling nitrous oxide. Although the players will not be disciplined, Rodgers emphasized the importance of professional responsibility and the need for young players to understand the consequences of their actions. The manager also mentioned the importance of learning from losses and setbacks in order to improve and progress. He did not comment on whether Steven Gerrard, who is available after a suspension, would be recalled for the upcoming match against Aston Villa.

Mesut Ozil, an Arsenal playmaker, enjoyed his time in London after the international break, as seen in a picture with his dog on Twitter. He was in good form during the Euro 2016 qualifier where Germany won 2-0 against Georgia. Ozil, who joined Arsenal from Real Madrid in 2013, is expected to play in the upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. He has been performing well since returning from injury, with four assists and three goals since January. Ozil claims to be adjusting well to English football, preferring the busy schedule of matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has confirmed that the club has no plans to replace Luis Enrique, expressing satisfaction with his performance. Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer, is close to winning the title with Barcelona. Bartomeu praised Enrique's dedication and hard work, mentioning his preparation for a game against Valencia after a Champions League match. Enrique's contract runs until 2016, and Barcelona is in a position to win three trophies in the season. Enrique's team, including players like Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, recently defeated Valencia in a match.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, set to run until 2020, with improved terms worth around £100,000 per week. Henderson, 24, has been a key player for Liverpool, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. He is expected to replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume in the summer, with Liverpool's CEO expecting Sterling to remain at the club for a long time. Henderson's new deal follows contract extensions for Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho.

Filipe Luis has expressed his desire to remain at Chelsea until the end of his three-year contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in him. He has faced competition for the left back position at Chelsea but remains committed to the club. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho emphasizes focus and winning in the upcoming challenging matches as the team competes for the Premier League title. Luis is now concentrating on the Premier League after playing for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal. The incident occurred on March 27 when Hughes, playing for Northampton, collided with North's head while scoring a try. Despite initial criticism, the appeal panel concluded there was no foul play and Hughes was cleared to return to action. The decision was met with relief from Wasps and support from other players, with Hughes missing only one game due to the ban. George North was advised to take a month off due to concussion symptoms from the third head injury in two months.

A fiery sunset in Washington, caused by raging wildfires in Siberia, has caught the attention of locals. The fires, started by farmers burning grass, grew out of control due to strong winds and spread throughout the region, destroying dozens of villages. The smoke from the fires was carried across the Pacific Ocean by atmospheric winds, resulting in intense red sunsets in the Pacific Northwest. The red color is due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from the sunlight, allowing red and orange to penetrate the air unfiltered. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Missouri mom Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway but was returned with red rims, red detailing, and orange steering wheel accents. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the car thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her vehicle. She plans to clean the car to remove the smell of cigarettes and marijuana and is creating a smoothie at her restaurant to honor the man who found her car.

Manchester City players, including Sergio Aguero and Yaya Toure, risk losing £500,000 in bonuses each if they fail to qualify for the Champions League. The team, managed by Manuel Pellegrini, is currently in fourth place and faces a crucial match against Liverpool. The City squad has about £12 million at stake based on their European performance. Pellegrini has acknowledged the team's poor performance in the past months, and they are now competing for signings like Paul Pogba against Manchester United.

In a local Manchester United Under 18s vs City match, United won 1-0 with Callum Gribbin scoring a free-kick. The match, played at Altrincham's 6,000-capacity ground, featured mostly English players, with 10 Mancunians. The game was part of the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series, with United now two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand. The match showcased local talents like Marcus Rashford and Callum Gribbin, who may deserve first-team opportunities.

Joe Hart, an England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon reached his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw against England. Hart, who celebrated his 50th cap at the Juventus Stadium, expressed admiration for Buffon's performance and aspired to continue his own career, aiming to add more caps for his country. Despite being 10 years younger than Buffon, Hart looks up to the Italian veteran and finds his achievements inspirational.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver orders in 67 cities. The service will include a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. Chipotle previously declined offers from third-party delivery services but has now partnered with Postmates, which uses independent contractors for deliveries. Other franchises, such as Starbucks and Taco Bell, are also exploring delivery options. Notably, presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton have been seen dining at Chipotle.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, are advocating for the removal of the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty for the bombings that killed their son and injured their daughter. They wish for Tsarnaev to spend the rest of his life in prison without parole or appeal rights, to avoid prolonged legal processes and further emotional distress. They emphasize their personal stance and desire to move forward for the sake of their remaining children and the community.

A mystery billionaire has transformed a Boeing 747 into a luxurious private home, customised to his specifications over three years, costing £400 million. The converted jumbo jet, which usually accommodates 600 passengers, has been redesigned to cater to a single owner and his guests, featuring bedrooms, lounges, an onboard restaurant, a dining room, a kitchen, a conference room, and a'state room'. The aircraft also includes an 'aeroloft' with eight full beds, a lounge with a TV area, and a master bedroom with a large bed, armchair, and sofa. The luxurious interior, designed by Greenpoint Technologies, offers a hotel-like ambience, with traditional aeroplane seating discarded in favour of a more comfortable and exclusive experience.

SpaceX launched an uncrewed Falcon 9 rocket carrying a Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station. The rocket's first-stage landing attempt on a floating barge was unsuccessful. The smaller, top part of the rocket will carry the Dragon into orbit and then burn up in Earth's atmosphere. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station and later return with over 3,000 pounds of science experiments and other items. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the ISS and the second attempt for this mission.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding in a new Las Vegas chapel of love, a contest in collaboration with NBC's Today show. The winning couple, to be announced next Monday, will marry at Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in the Westgate Hotel on April 23. The couple will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. No impersonators are allowed. Couples must submit a video or photos with an explanation to win the opportunity to be the first to wed at the chapel. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside his Memphis home.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can close the gap with Manchester City in the Premier League after a challenging season. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet reached 47 appearances in a 2-0 win over Newcastle, matching a record in Europe's top leagues. Henderson sees an opportunity to pressure City, who are four points ahead but recently lost 4-2 to Manchester United. Raheem Sterling scored early, and Joe Allen secured the win with a second goal, despite a controversial non-penalty call. Henderson emphasizes the importance of maintaining winning form to potentially overtake City by season's end.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli in Serie A on Saturday, with Miralem Pjanic scoring in the 25th minute and Morgan de Sanctis making crucial saves in the second half. The victory moved Roma four points clear of city rivals Lazio and extended Napoli's winless streak to five matches. Tight security measures were in place for the match, and Roma was without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho. Napoli had a chance for a penalty but did not protest, and Lorenzo Insigne made his first appearance since tearing his knee in November.

The passage describes a lackluster football season for Doncaster Rovers in League One, with a particularly unexciting match against Fleetwood Town resulting in a 0-0 draw. The media team's challenge to create an engaging highlight reel for the match led to a brief 27-second video featuring only the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

The passage describes a man, Roland Giroux, who interacts with his blood parrot cichlid fish by gently massaging it and playing with it daily. The fish, which used to be bullied by other tank mates, has become sociable and enjoys the human interaction. Giroux noticed the fish's increased sociability after feeding it by hand and spending time with it daily. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan in 1986.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team after a year of challenges, including a broken wrist and a reputation for fiery behavior. Stokes is known for his aggression and exuberance, which can be both an asset and a liability. The England coach, Peter Moores, has advised Stokes on managing his aggression and maintaining his natural character while focusing on delivering runs and wickets. The team aims to balance Stokes' freedom with occasional restraint, and they value his presence in the team alongside fellow player Chris Jordan. The summer season will likely not require two spinners, allowing Stokes and Jordan to develop further in the international game.

The Wales vs Belgium Euro 2016 qualifier at Cardiff City Stadium on June 12 has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams have 11 points, but Belgium leads due to better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel has raised hopes for qualification. Ticket demand was high, and the Wales team prefers the Cardiff City Stadium over the Millennium Stadium for its intimacy.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, which includes players from various Premier League clubs. The Young Lions, who are the defending champions, will compete in Group D against Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. The squad features talented young players such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo of Chelsea, Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi of Arsenal, and Liverpool pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold. The team will play their first match against Italy on May 7.

Manchester City is interested in signing Anderlecht teenager Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly-regarded 14-year-old playmaker. Patoulidis has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to focus on his studies. Manchester City has been in talks with Anderlecht to agree on a compensation package, as they aim to build for the future with this promising talent.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the death of transgender escort Vanessa Santillan, who was found strangled and beaten in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London. The 33-year-old Mexican national died from head and neck injuries. Police are appealing for witnesses who had contact with her in the hours before her death, and Scotland Yard is investigating the case.

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to discuss the theft of £207 set aside for her baby's grave stone by her friend and housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar. Despite initial denials, a lie detector test revealed Jamie's guilt. He had confessed to taking the money in a Facebook message but blamed his girlfriend Carol. Dawn expressed her distress and feelings of betrayal, as she had intended to use the money to honor her baby, Daniel James.

ISIS has released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group from northern Iraq, with most being women and children, as well as some ill and elderly individuals. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders and the Yazidis were received by the Peshmerga and sent to Irbil. The motivation behind the release is unclear. The Yazidis, who have a pre-Islamic religion, have faced extreme persecution from ISIS, including slaughter, rape, and enslavement. An international coalition has responded with airdrops, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS. There are an estimated 500,000 Yazidis in northern Iraq.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham striker, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. He has had an impressive season, scoring 20 Premier League goals, including a long-range strike against Chelsea and a headed goal against Arsenal. A Copa90 video titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' showcases his best goals and celebrations from the season, and was released ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the Liverpool manager despite a trophy-less season and potential failure to finish in the top four. Carragher believes Rodgers should not be judged solely on this season's performance and highlights the need for the right player signings to strengthen the squad. Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, received a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside and hopes to inspire youngsters in the area.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security concerns. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was mistaken for a prohibited item on the X-ray system. James was frisked and his toy was taken, leading to his father, Phil, criticizing the security staff for being over-zealous. The family was offered a replacement toy or to have the confiscated toy mailed back to them. The airport defended its actions, citing regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited items.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, named Rich, has posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He has listed several requirements for his ideal partner, including love for pets, non-smoking and non-drinking habits, fitness, reliability, and cooking skills. Rich describes himself as athletic, non-drinker, non-smoker, and successful, with a love for the outdoors and sports. He promises benefits and an open mind to "reasonable offers" from potential partners.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke has support from five former England managers in his bid to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in Premier League club squads from eight to 12 and change the definition of 'home-grown' to include players trained in England for three years before the age of 18. The former managers warn that failing to implement these changes risks England falling further behind leading football nations and prolonging the country's wait to win the World Cup. They also highlight the emergence of young talents like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, emphasizing the need for more opportunities for young players.

Demelza Poldark, in the show "Poldark," has rapidly progressed from barely showing signs of pregnancy to giving birth within a short time frame. The show features Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, who is admired by many but remains emotionally unavailable. Despite the quick progression of Demelza's pregnancy, from announcement to birth, fans have humorously noted the show's unrealistic portrayal of pregnancy timelines.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has advised his team to focus on their own performance and not get distracted by their relegation rivals. Following back-to-back wins, including a last-minute victory against West Brom, Pearson emphasized the importance of maintaining focus and not getting involved in speculation about other teams. He believes that Leicester's future is in their own hands and that they have a realistic chance of survival if they concentrate on their own games.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest recorded mammal migration, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia to Baja, Mexico. The journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's trip, which included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggests that some western gray whales may actually be eastern grays. This could have implications for the estimated population of western gray whales, which is believed to be around 150.

A 1,000ft stretch of seabed was forced to the surface on Hokkaido Island's east coast in Japan due to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The newly emerged landmass, which rose 30-50ft above sea level, measures roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Local residents were surprised by the sudden appearance of the land, as there were no tremors or sounds indicating the movement. Authorities believe the landslide is unrelated to the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in Nepal. Marine organisms are still attached to the landmass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied plans to leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc, Van der Wiel is content and looking to sign a new contract. However, Paris Saint-Germain's interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves could impact his position in the team.

Carlos Tevez has expressed a desire to leave Juventus and return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina, despite his contract running until 2016. Boca Juniors are close to finalizing a deal for Tevez, but he must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Tevez has been a prolific scorer for Juventus, with 17 goals this season. His international manager, Tata Martino, believes Tevez's potential move will not affect his future with the Argentina national team.

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in his grey trousers, exposing his underwear. Despite this mishap, Bayern defeated Porto 6-1, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski. This victory secured Bayern's place in the Champions League semi-finals, showcasing their dominance over Porto.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in various injuries. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, while a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also evacuated. Six others with minor injuries were taken to Ipswich Hospital. One person was trapped in their vehicle and freed by rescue crews. The highway was closed with diversions in place, and police anticipated it would reopen in a few hours.

The passage discusses Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil's excitement for his new Apple Watch, which he received as a gift and compared to the watch of TV character Michael Knight from Knight Rider. The article also highlights the return of Jack Wilshere from injury and his potential impact on the team, as noted by club legend Ray Parlour. Despite Arsenal's 10-point deficit to Chelsea in the Premier League, the team is hopeful for the upcoming match and the continued contribution of Wilshere, provided he can maintain his fitness.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will oversee the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford. This season, Clattenburg has sent off three players from the two teams, with both red cards issued to United players. City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for the match due to a double booking in a previous game. Clattenburg, despite past controversies, is considered one of the Premier League's top referees. The derby is significant as United is a point above City in the league table, with both teams aiming to secure the second spot behind Chelsea.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of believing that embattled MP Billy Gordon, who was recently accused of domestic violence and withholding his criminal history, would resign. Katter, of Lebanese descent, sympathized with Gordon and criticized the government's racial assumptions, sparking social media criticism. Katter defended his use of the term 'black puppet', saying it was based on his personal experiences and understanding of racial attitudes. He also compared Gordon to federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott, who he believes became government puppets, but vowed Gordon would not make the same mistake.

A 19-year-old Illinois teenager, Dayna Dobias, who has cerebral palsy, is creating dance videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. Born with cerebral palsy, Dayna has faced bullying and stares but aims to show that she is just like everyone else, despite doing things a little differently. Her videos, including one dancing to Taylor Swift's Shake It Off, aim to entertain, inspire, and encourage people to look past disabilities. Dayna has also started motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, coached by Adrian Heath, is interested in Manchester United player Javier Hernandez due to his potential commercial draw for the club with a large Latin-American fanbase. Hernandez, who had a difficult loan at Real Madrid, is also sought after by eight European teams. Manchester United is considering offers around £8million for Hernandez. Meanwhile, United has made a new contract offer to Andreas Pereira, a 19-year-old midfielder, who has other European clubs interested in him.

A group of three or more individuals attempted to carjack a man at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning. During an argument, the suspects poured gasoline on the man's white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers were inside. The driver and passengers were unharmed, but the car was completely destroyed. The incident is being investigated as arson by the Los Angeles County Fire Department, with surveillance video being used in the investigation. The man's grandmother reported that the fire was started after the suspects tried to carjack her grandson.

A chiropractor in southern Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his license after being accused of accepting sex as payment and performing exorcisms on patients. He admitted to these misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite his actions, Manuel received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. He must prove that the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can practice again. Manuel's practice was located on a residential street in Lamoni.

The United States has lodged a complaint with Russia following an incident where a Russian fighter jet intercepted a U.S. reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner." The U.S. RC-135U was flying in international airspace when the Russian SU-27 Flanker performed aggressive maneuvers close to the U.S. aircraft. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was off its transponder and approaching the Russian border, which the U.S. denied. This is not the first such incident, with a similar event occurring a year prior over the Sea of Okhotsk. The U.S. plans to address the issue through diplomatic channels.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car's window at a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was secured with padlocks and chains, but was still forcefully taken by breaking the window and cutting the case's handle. The agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. The hotel, located next to the city's airport and the state's FBI office, does not have surveillance cameras. The stolen rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was notified before President Obama's visit. The rifle has not been recovered.

A 71-year-old man, Luigi Costa, is accused of killing his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in 2012. Costa allegedly suffered from dementia and alcohol abuse, which may have contributed to his confused mental state during the crime. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and believes his brain was compromised by dementia and alcohol, leading to a fluctuating mood and confusion. The jury can return a not guilty verdict if Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty during a 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines' superior record. Barkley missed the penalty, but Mirallas scored the only goal of the game later on. Martinez believes in having multiple players capable of taking penalties based on their feelings at the moment.

Two passengers on a Holland America Line cruise ship in Puerto Rico were found dead in their stateroom, with the situation appearing to be a murder-suicide. The incident was reported to the authorities, including the FBI, and the ship was cooperating with the investigation. The deceased were discovered by the cleaning staff after knocking on their cabin door. The ship had departed Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was in San Juan, Puerto Rico, at the time of the incident.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to the second round of the 2018 World Cup qualification in CONCACAF. Curacao won 4-3 on aggregate against Montserrat, with Kluivert's team previously winning 2-1. Kluivert, who is of Curacao descent, was a World Cup semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and assisted coach Louis van Gaal in 2014. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round.

Esteban Cambiasso, a successful European football player, has joined Leicester City in the Premier League and aims to help the team avoid relegation. Cambiasso, who has won numerous major European competitions throughout his career, compares the challenge of keeping Leicester in the Premier League to winning another trophy. Despite the team's struggles, Cambiasso remains optimistic and believes they can secure enough points to stay in the league. He is content with his life in the East Midlands and may extend his contract beyond the current one-year deal.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother-of-two, is at risk of losing visitation rights to her children due to her ongoing alcohol and drug use, partying lifestyle, and alleged theft. Gemma's mother, Debbie, who has been caring for the children since they were four months old, is considering banning Gemma from seeing the children because of her irresponsible behavior and lack of trust in Gemma not to steal from them. Gemma has a history of underage drinking, sex, and theft, and has been unemployed. Debbie believes Gemma is not fit to be a mother and prioritizes her partying lifestyle over her children.

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Chelsea's John Terry committed a strong challenge from behind on United's Radamel Falcao, leading to a foul. Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway after a tire blew out, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira in 384 BC. At 17, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens, where he stayed until 347 BC. After Plato's death, Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon, starting in 343 BC.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked German federal state bordering Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest and sixth most populous state in Germany, with an area of 18,413 km2 and a population of 4 million. Jennifer Lopez entered the music industry in 1999 with her debut album, On the 6. She became the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week in 2001. A working animal is a domesticated creature trained by humans to perform specific tasks, such as guide dogs, draft horses, or milking animals. Its applications range from voice user interfaces, call routing, and control of domestic appliances to search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft systems. Richard Alf, an American businessman and ex-comic book store owner, co-founded San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 and served as its chairman. The convention was initially known as the Golden State Comic Book Convention and was founded by a group of San Diegans, including Alf, Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. It was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
The passage discusses 'Fist of Legend,' a remake of the 1972 film 'Fist of Fury,' which featured Bruce Lee in the lead role.

In a golf tournament, Dubuisson from France tied with Van Zyl of South Africa at 16 under par, while McIlroy from Northern Ireland moved to 15 under par with a consistent performance, aiming for his first win since May. McIlroy, recovering from an ankle injury, is seeking his third Race to Dubai title, leading Danny Willett by 271 points. English golfers Chris Wood and Richard Bland are in fifth and seventh place.

The passage details the passing of influential early-music movement figure, Hogwood, who founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) and worked with leading orchestras globally. He was a renowned conductor, musicologist, and keyboard player, with notable recordings such as Handel's Messiah. Hogwood was also an educator at prestigious universities. His legacy continues through the AAM and the many musicians he mentored. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a decrease from the previous year and the lowest since 1976. A sharp instrument, usually a knife, was the most common method of killing, with 29 cases involving knives. Alcohol or drugs were involved in 31% of the cases. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts in education and enforcement to prevent violent crime. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker cautioned that while homicide rates are decreasing, sexual crime is at a 45-year high and violent crime has increased by 27%.

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking Sunderland's first Premier League win of the season. Despite creating numerous chances, Bournemouth failed to score, even with Sunderland down to 10 men. Manager Howe expressed disappointment but emphasized the need to move on from the loss.

The passage discusses Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's stance on stopping migrant boats to prevent deaths at sea, Australia's offshore processing policy, and criticism from the New York Times. Abbott defends his position, citing the need to stop illegal boats, and compares the Islamic State to the Nazis, sparking controversy and criticism from Australian Jewish groups.

The US has suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia, which were established to sustain the cessation of hostilities in Syria, due to Russia and the Syrian government intensifying attacks against civilians. The US had warned Russia to stop bombing Aleppo, but Russia and the Syrian regime continued their military course, targeting critical infrastructure and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians. Russia denies involvement in the deadly aid convoy strike. The US will withdraw personnel in anticipation of the possible establishment of the Joint US-Russian Implementation Centre, but both sides will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations in Syria.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, from Swansea, died after contracting measles during an epidemic in the city. He was recently treated for asthma but died shortly after developing a rash. Although measles was confirmed, an inquest is needed to determine the exact cause of death. Since November, 83 people have been hospitalized due to the outbreak. The family is unsure how Gareth contracted measles, as no close relatives, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with an offence against a boy under 16, reportedly occurring in 2001. He is set to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court. The incident took place in Cumbria.

Guiseley and Gateshead ended in a 1-1 draw in a National League match. Guiseley took the lead with a goal from Jake Lawlor, but Gateshead equalized with a shot from Wes York. Both teams had a player sent off with yellow cards. Guiseley's Derek Asamoah was substituted in the second half, while Gateshead made two substitutions, including Luke Hannant for Gus Mafuta.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands at their football club to increase capacity, as an alternative to a delayed new stadium proposal at Ashton Vale. The redevelopment plan was approved by Bristol City Council and confirmed by majority shareholder Steve Lansdown. Work will commence after signing a section 106 agreement and a six-week judicial review period, with the project starting in May if no issues arise.

The passage discusses the suspension of shale gas drilling (fracking) by Cuadrilla in Lancashire, UK, due to a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is examining the data to decide on resuming operations. Fracking involves releasing gas from underground rocks using hydraulic pressure or explosions, which has caused controversy due to potential environmental impacts. The BGS stated that any process injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes. The latest tremor was felt by at least one person in Poulton-Le-Fylde, and its epicenter was within 2km of the drilling site. The BGS is monitoring the situation closely.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool piper, was found guilty of one count of fraud for using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes while busking in 2015, but was cleared of two other counts. He claimed to be collecting donations for the charity, but the chairman stated permission was given only to display the banner, not to collect funds. Carpenter argued the banner was a tribute to the victims and not a deceptive act. He will be sentenced in January.

The passage discusses Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, who had a successful T20 Blast season, scoring 373 runs with an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed his enthusiasm about the club's direction and the high-performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive victory by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were instrumental in the win. Churcher highlighted the team's strong performance in tackling, with the front row and front five making over 70 tackles. The Reds have seven teams below them in the table to play in their next eight games, including league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher emphasized the need for continuous improvement and building on their recent performance.

The police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul, a Bangladeshi citizen, raped a 74-year-old nun in India, leading to widespread outrage and protests. Nazrul, identified as the sixth arrest in the case, was apprehended at a Kolkata railway station based on a tip-off. Five other suspects have previously identified Nazrul as the perpetrator. The attack, which also involved theft and vandalism at a convent school, was led by a gang, with Milon Sarkar as a possible leader, though his exact role remains unclear.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explaining factors influencing consumer purchasing changes such as the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also examines the shifting ownership and ranking of major UK brands. The video may not be compatible with older browsers, and a non-interactive version is available. The passage also mentions additional resources on related topics.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills and another from Stranraer were deceived by scammers posing as BT technical support. The fraudsters gained remote access to the victims' computers and stole money. The Sandyhills incident occurred on 15 September, followed by the Stranraer case seven days later. Police urge people to be cautious when receiving cold calls requesting remote computer access and to never disclose banking details over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, currently in third place in the Championship. He will lead the team in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy has been praised for his work at Swinton Lions under difficult circumstances. He previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford and has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, medic, and coastguard helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach for a rider with head injuries and hypothermia from lying unconscious on wet sand. The individual was treated and transported to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to allocate a radio frequency for global flight tracking via satellite, improving upon the current ground-based radar system. This decision was influenced by the disappearance of flight MH370 in 2014, which highlighted the limitations of the existing system. The new system will enable real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world through automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes or more in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found at age 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. The FBI, working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed Julian's identity after a college application issue. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested on unrelated charges of tampering with records for a driver's license and is being held at Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. It was suspected at the time of Julian's disappearance that his father might be involved.

Firefighters responded to a blaze on Duncan Street on 2 March, causing travel disruptions. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste due to fire safety concerns, despite the company being "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The company, managed by Asset and Land Group, has until 7 August to appeal the decision. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the site nine times in the past year and raised concerns about the potential impact of a fire on residents, transport, and the environment. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, and the company must still remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed bills in response to the situation in Ukraine, particularly in Crimea, where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The bills would allow territories to join Russia more easily, without needing a treaty or the state's consent, if they express a desire to do so. The second bill would expedite the process of issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, especially those who are Russian-speaking, without requiring a state tax, previous Russian residence, or sufficient funds. The bills are seen as a way to support Russian-speaking Ukrainians facing the "brown threat."

The passage discusses McLaren's decline from a dominant force in Formula 1 to its current struggles. Once a team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, McLaren now finds itself fighting for the fourth row on the grid. The decline began in 2013 due to poor chassis design, despite having a strong engine. Although the team has shown improvement in car design, issues with the Honda power-unit persist. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of success and decline, with the team currently hoping for a resurgence under the leadership of Ron Dennis. Despite past achievements and having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Jenson Button, the team has struggled in recent years, with hopes resting on the progress of their car and Honda's engine development.

Tommy Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was shot in the head and chest outside Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January and later died in the hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and remain in custody. The shooting occurred after Baker left Phoenix Gym at the market, where the suspects had been waiting for about an hour. Police are searching for a silver VW polo that left the scene and are appealing for witnesses who may have seen the vehicle or the incident.

The passage discusses various ways people are using technology to celebrate and share Christmas traditions and religious messages. It highlights the launch of Everyday Church Online, which offers virtual services and sermons, including a Star Wars-themed Christmas sermon. The passage also mentions Guardians of Ancora, a free-to-play fantasy game that teaches children about the Bible through quests and stories. Additionally, it covers the success of viral Christmas videos, such as The Digital Story of Nativity and Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle, which use social media platforms to share the Christmas story. Finally, the passage discusses the use of Manga to share biblical stories, with the Manga Messiah being available in 33 languages.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is evaluating a proposal to develop 250 hectares of common land, with the backing of Blaenau Gwent council and a promise of 800 acres of replacement land. Expert opinions are divided on the potential environmental impact, with Natural Resources Wales expressing uncertainty about the replacement land's value, while developers claim a net gain in biodiversity through habitat enhancement. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend a decision to Welsh government ministers.

Chechen Muslim clerics convened on 3 April to express outrage over a report that insulted their faith and Chechen men, calling for retribution against the report's instigators. The report, published by Novaya Gazeta on 1 April, claimed over 100 individuals suspected of being homosexual were detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, highlighting the region's widespread homophobia. Ramzan Kadyrov, the authoritarian leader of Chechnya, denied the allegations, and his spokesman claimed there were no gay people in Chechnya. The Chechen spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, supported the call for retribution. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor responded by stating the paper's commitment to investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya and urging dialogue. The LGBT Network is assisting people in fleeing persecution in Chechnya and may file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to pro

Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing, both based in south London, have been working together to provide housing for single homeless men over 35. Investing Solutions receives benefit payments and rents properties from private landlords, while Fresh Start refers clients to them. The letting agent profits by charging housing benefit for each individual housed in a single property, rather than the total rent for the property. This has led to concerns about the suitability of the housing provided and the high profits made by Investing Solutions. Nearly half of Investing Solutions' funding comes from Wandsworth Council. Both organizations claim to operate within legal boundaries, but their practices have been criticized as exploitative.

In a basketball game, London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13 for Coach Joe Prunty's team. The team led for most of the first three quarters but lost in the last 10 minutes to the Dutch. Gordon performed well, especially in the third quarter. The loss was a setback for GB's Eurobasket qualifying campaign, with their next game in Hungary. Prunty emphasized the need for consistent effort and focus on every play.

The former five-weight world champion submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for using 8oz gloves in a bout against Mayweather, who plans to use 10oz gloves. The NAC will debate the matter on 16 August. McGregor, who has used 4oz gloves in the UFC, will make his boxing debut against Mayweather. The NAC executive director believes there are reasons to approve the fight, citing McGregor's performance against Nate Diaz and his age, height, and reach advantage over Mayweather. McGregor has hired boxing referee Joe Cortez for the fight.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith worked for the Dundee-based Sunday Post, which closes its London office on Fleet Street. Once a hub for the nation's biggest newspapers, Fleet Street was home to nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published there in 1702. The street was known for its bars and pubs, where journalists socialized and sought stories. However, the rise of television and social media, along with the move of media companies to cheaper locations, led to the decline of Fleet Street. The last two journalists from the Sunday Post have now left, marking the end of an era.

The passage discusses J.K. Rowling's experience with online criticism due to her political views and donations. She received abusive comments and was called a traitor for donating to the campaign against Scottish independence and to the Labour party. Rowling blocked some abusive users, stating she doesn't need to protect any political party's image. She also engaged in discussions with SNP supporters, finding common political ground. The passage mentions the SNP's success in the recent election and includes Rowling's humorous response to a suggestion of burning her books.

The University of Edinburgh study found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and are more likely to engage in violence. Poverty increases the likelihood of young people offending and being placed on statutory supervision. Gender is also a predictor of violence, with boys being more likely to engage in violent acts and girls from poorer backgrounds twice as likely to be involved in violent crime. The study highlights a destructive dynamic where poverty increases the risks of violence and contact with the juvenile justice system exacerbates these risks. Despite a decrease in crime rates in Scotland, areas with the highest crime rates are still the most deprived communities. The Scottish government claims Scotland is becoming safer, with initiatives to tackle poverty and inequality.

Robbie Walsh, 25, from Island View, Kilrush, was charged with causing serious harm to Karl Haugh, who was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee. Walsh, along with two others, was arrested but only Walsh was remanded in custody. The incident occurred when Walsh and two others looked for Haugh, leading to a fight involving multiple individuals. Haugh was fatally wounded and died at the hospital. Knives and golf clubs were recovered from the scene, and Walsh is due in court again on 14th August. Two other men arrested were released without charge.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted a false accusation about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, suggesting he had harassed and shot people during his service. Elliott, who has a clear MoD record, was alerted to the tweet by campaigner Ann Travers and DUP's Arlene Foster. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and later apologized, stating the tweet was untrue and without foundation. The court is yet to decide on the compensation amount, and Flanagan's insurance firm refuses to cover the costs. Elliott expressed satisfaction with the outcome, stating he was vindicated and disappointed with the time it took to resolve the issue.

Hawick Knitwear, a company founded in 1874 and acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, has increased its sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 per week due to higher demand for its private label and own-branded ranges. The company employs over 230 staff and sells its products in Europe and markets outside Europe, including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop attributes the success to the dedicated staff and expects continued growth in the future.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was hit by Brian Wright's VW Golf while crossing the road at a red light, resulting in serious head injuries. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and does not remember the traffic light's color. The court heard that the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Wright's eyes. The trial continues.

The passage discusses a NATO exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose," which is a response to increased Russian submarine activity in the waters near the UK, Sweden, and Finland. The exercise involves a German U-boat, U33, simulating an enemy submarine attempting to evade detection by NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland. The passage highlights the challenges of anti-submarine warfare, the technological advancements of Russian submarines, and the importance of long-range maritime patrol aircraft. The UK's lack of such aircraft is identified as a significant gap in its defenses, with Britain relying on NATO allies for surveillance. The exercise aims to ensure NATO readiness for anti-submarine warfare and underscores the need for the UK to address its defense vulnerabilities.

The United Nations has expressed concern over potential genocide and ethnic cleansing in South Sudan, where violence since July has forced 340,000 people to flee to Uganda, surpassing the number of Syrian refugees in 2016. The civil war, initially a dispute between President Salva Kiir (Dinka) and former Vice-President Riek Machar (Nuer), has escalated to include targeting of Equatorians. Refugees, like Nelson Ladu Thomas and his family, have escaped horrific violence, including killings and rapes. Uganda, initially welcoming and providing land and resources to refugees, is now struggling to cope with the influx, especially with water supply issues. The crisis has left many children orphaned and traumatized, as illustrated by the poem of 16-year-old Patricia Mercy.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old professional boxer, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on 12 November at York Hall. He started boxing in 2013 after leaving football and has a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage discusses a £33m investment by the coalition for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital in England, which will replace the old 1813 facility. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and diagnostic spaces. The project is funded by the coalition, NHS Somerset, and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The current hospital is described as outdated and in need of constant repairs. The new hospital is expected to improve patient recovery and provide a modern one-stop shop for healthcare services. Construction is planned on land at Bowers Lane, with a target completion date of autumn 2014, following the acquisition of planning permission.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre. The victim, a family member, was either in or near his black Mercedes when he was attacked. Despite being taken to Northern General hospital, he succumbed to his gunshot wound. The incident occurred during a family celebration, with relatives and neighbors attempting to assist him after the shooting. This area has recently experienced several shootings, though they were previously confined to the city's northern parts.

The passage discusses the activities of various cyber groups involved in the Ukrainian conflict. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for hacking Russian servers, using DDoS attacks, and hijacking CCTV systems to gather intelligence and disrupt separatist activities. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, targets Ukrainian government websites and claims to have hacked electronic billboards to display anti-Ukrainian messages. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, publishes leaked documents related to Russia's domestic affairs and Ukraine, but its methods of obtaining information are unclear.

In a Scottish parliament session, veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and First Minister Alex Salmond delivered emotional farewell speeches before stepping down in the upcoming election. Salmond emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for greater self-governance, while McNeil highlighted the importance of accountability and scrutiny in Holyrood. Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick expressed gratitude for their contributions. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also announced her retirement.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their families, and care providers to share their experiences to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will examine factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but criticizes the lack of provider representation on the advisory panel.

The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, experienced an £800,000 increase in pre-tax profit, reaching £3.5 million, despite a £1 million drop in turnover, totaling just over £100 million, in the year ending June 2016. The company credited growth in international sales, particularly in Europe and new markets, for its profit increase. Harbro, which produces and supplies feed for various livestock sectors and operates 19 shops in Scotland under the Country Store brand, acknowledged the unpredictable agricultural outlook and potential impact of Brexit but expressed confidence in its ability to navigate future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, with an 80-year-old man also hospitalized. Detectives are investigating the case as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin. He is described as a white male, about 6ft tall, with greying collar-length hair. Police are urging anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols are being conducted in the area for resident reassurance.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, expressed concerns about the global economy's weakening baseline in a speech. This follows weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, with a significant drop in exports. The IMF is likely to downgrade its global growth forecast of 3.4% in April. This situation has ongoing implications for businesses and industries relying on China's growth.

The council scrutiny meeting addressed issues with the new vessel, with Cowes crossing being free until July 2nd to gather feedback. The council initiated a project review by auditors after a problematic start, including breakdowns, groundings, and training issues leading to suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Local businesses, like Valu-4-U, suffered from trade loss, questioning compensation for damages and lost business. Councillor Ian Ward suggested compensation discussions and mentioned that the issues were expected with a prototype, including electrical problems that were fixed, and that ramp extensions were authorized to prevent vehicle damage. Groundings were attributed to seamanship, which has been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, resulting in a 32-year-old man's death. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook for investigation until early evening.

Matching Models, an international temp agency in London, has faced criticism for its discriminatory job advertisements, including one seeking a personal assistant with specific physical attributes. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners have condemned the agency's approach, which they believe violates equality legislation. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, stating that looks are important to their clients. However, employment lawyer James Lynas warned that the use of phrases like "beautiful and attractive" could be seen as code for "young" and discriminatory against older women. The agency has clients such as MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods.

A shooting at a hostel linked to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, India, involved an office assistant named Mahesh, who allegedly shot 18-year-old Gautami and another student, Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. The motive for the shooting is unclear. India has strict gun control laws, but firearms are still used in feuds. In 2007, a 14-year-old was shot dead at a school near Delhi.

The Glaad advocacy group's analysis of shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found 278 LGBT characters, with a rise in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith.
