The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. The study considered scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series. Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis mentioned progress but emphasized that numbers are "only part of the story".

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, has decided to not stand for re-election after facing opposition within his party over a controversial loan to Northampton Town FC. The loan, which was meant for stadium redevelopment, is now under police investigation due to missing funds of around £10.25m. Despite initially planning to run for re-election, Mackintosh has chosen to step down, stating it's time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards by firing a rifle into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Dallas. The incident occurred in April, following reports of underage drinking. Initially, police claimed the car reversed aggressively towards Oliver, but video evidence showed the car was moving away. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official. He faces 5 to 99 years in prison for the murder charge. If convicted, he would be the first Dallas County police officer convicted of murder since 1973. The trial date has not been set.

The president-elect has announced that Melania Trump and their son Barron will move to Washington after he finishes school, but no date has been set. This decision has sparked criticism on social media, with some people expressing disappointment and others speculating about the reasons behind it. However, it is not uncommon for first families to prioritize their children's education over moving into the White House. Historically, there have been only two first ladies who did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. Melania Trump has indicated that Barron will be her top priority, suggesting she may not take on the full-time role of a first lady like her predecessors. The role of the first lady is mainly ceremonial, but in recent times, they have also sought out causes to support and promote. Melania Trump has expressed interest in tackling cyber-bullying.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness, prompting an investigation by the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) into the police's initial response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) upon completion.

A yellow wind warning has been issued, predicting gusts up to 75mph, particularly affecting areas west of the mountains due to an unusual easterly direction. This could cause travel disruptions on roads and at sea. The affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. A fallen tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey has led to the closure of Telford Road for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants initially lead due to a goal by Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen evens the score for the Panthers. Mike Forney scores a powerplay breakaway goal, followed by Andy Bohmback's equalizer. Mike Radja and James Desmarais contribute to the Panthers' lead, with David Ling scoring for Nottingham. The teams will face off again on Saturday, with Nottingham leading the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27, and Belfast with 25.

In a Formula 1 race, World Champion Hamilton started last due to a broken front wing and made five pit stops, while Sebastian Vettel of Ferrari came in second despite a collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen. Raikkonen managed to pass Hamilton towards the end, aided by Ferrari's choice of soft tyres. Hamilton, now facing a 36-point deficit, remains confident despite the challenges. The race was marked by multiple collisions and incidents, including a notable confrontation between Vettel and Red Bull's Daniil Kvyat post-race. Daniel Ricciardo of Red Bull initially led but was forced to retire early due to a puncture. Lewis Hamilton's car was damaged in an early incident, affecting his performance. Mercedes' decision not to pit Hamilton under the safety car further hampered his chances. Hamilton now faces a significant challenge in closing the points gap with Rosberg.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a retired German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, becoming the most prominent footballer to do so in Germany. His announcement was praised by former teammates, football administrators, and other public figures, who saw it as a courageous step in the fight against homophobia in football. Hitzlsperger's decision is considered a watershed moment in Germany, where homosexuality in football has been a taboo subject. The German Football Association and other football figures hope that his announcement will encourage more openness about sexuality in the sport.

34-year-old Sidwell has made 32 Championship appearances for Brighton this season, contributing to their promotion to the Premier League after a 34-year absence. With his contract ending, he hopes to sign a new deal, expressing confidence in the team's ability to stay in the Premier League. Sidwell has previous Premier League experience with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke. He believes he deserves another opportunity to play at the top level.

In a football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, Nathan Delfouneso scored for Blackpool after 12 minutes, but Sam Slocombe saved a goal from Matthew Briggs. Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Blackpool after a corner. Colchester failed to take the lead before half-time due to Slocombe's save from George Elokobi and Guthrie hitting the bar. Blackpool missed a chance to win 15 minutes from time with Tom Aldred heading wide from a corner. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

A 29-year-old player, with experience at Sky Blues, Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for Sky Blues last season and may debut for Colchester in their EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa, following a 3-1 defeat at Accrington. The latest football transfers can be found on the dedicated page.

The passage discusses the UK Police Memorial Trust's appeal for £1.5 million to construct a permanent memorial for fallen officers, including PC Keith Palmer, at the National Memorial Arboretum. The memorial, set to be completed by 2019, will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes dedicated to the families of fallen officers. The UK government has committed £1 million towards the £4 million needed for the project. The memorial will honor over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives in the past 250 years.

United maintains a 15-point lead at the top of the table with eight games remaining, following a 1-0 win against Sunderland. Ferguson emphasizes focusing on the upcoming games, highlighting the team's record of 25 wins in the first 30 matches. The next match is a derby against Manchester City, with United aiming to surpass Chelsea's 2005 record of 95 points. Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries and player fatigue. He praises the team's determined defending and courage in the win against Sunderland.

The passage discusses Google's tax practices in the UK, with the company's chairman, Mr. Schmidt, stating that Google has been paying the legally required amount of taxes, which was £10m between 2006 and 2011. He suggests that changes to the tax system should be made by the government if they wish to alter the amount of tax paid by companies. The head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, Margaret Hodge, proposes the creation of a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of large firms, which could potentially force companies to disclose their tax affairs. Google has been criticized for its tax practices, with the company's chairman advocating for taxes to be levied where economic activity occurs, rather than where products are consumed. He also calls for a debate on international tax reform.

The NHS Improvement regulator has expressed a desire for more progress in reducing the NHS's agency bill, as the NHS has fallen behind schedule in this effort. Last year, £3.6bn was spent on agency staff, and the regulator aims to reduce this by £1bn by the end of the current financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m, but the NHS is still 10% behind its target. NHS Improvement plans to publish "league tables" of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending and will collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust. NHS Improvement chief executive Jim Mackey emphasized the need for further action to reduce spending on expensive agency staff.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a hub of commerce, is now a symbol of Ireland's economic downturn. However, local businesses like a family-owned men's clothing shop are beginning to see a slow recovery. Criticism is directed at the government's handling of the region, particularly regarding investment in water meters over broadband improvements. Despite this, the government has announced a potential investment in a tourism development by Center Parcs, which is yet to receive planning permission. Traders believe more can be done to boost the local economy, such as addressing parking charges. The overall sentiment is cautious optimism for economic recovery in the midlands.

The passage describes a cricket tournament with eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four qualifying for play-offs. The competition ends on 29 May in the same stadium. The BBC Sport website provides updates on scores, fixtures, and results. Key players' statistics are provided, including top run-scorers and wicket-takers. Four England players participate in the tournament. The passage also lists a detailed schedule of fixtures and results from 25 April to 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, causing environmental issues due to their non-recyclability and improper disposal. To combat this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags in October, following successful reductions in bag usage in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland where charges are already in place. The campaign aims to reduce plastic bag waste and benefit the environment.

A section of a school roof was blown off in Rhosgadfan, Caernarfon, causing power cuts and disruptions across Wales. The incident occurred after a yellow warning for wind, with train delays, bridge restrictions, and further power cuts reported. Irish Ferries cancelled sailings due to weather conditions, and Arriva Trains Wales issued speed restrictions and potential delays. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle due to high winds. Some travel restrictions were lifted in the evening, but a blustery forecast led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip.

The actor expressed excitement about working with director Ryan Coogler again on a new project, and looking forward to collaborating with Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, who plays Black Panther. The actor previously portrayed the Human Torch in Fantastic Four. Black Panther is set to release in February 2018.

The passage discusses the restoration of a theatre founded in 1875, located within Alexandra Palace, with the goal of reopening it in 2018 for various performances and screenings. The project includes refurbishing BBC studios and transforming the glazed east court into a public space. Funding is being sourced from the Heritage Lottery Fund, Haringey Council, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, with a total cost of £26.6m for the east wing refurbishment. The theatre retains much of its original features and has historical significance for showcasing diverse entertainment forms.

The passage discusses a 30-year-old former Manchester City player who has represented England 61 times since his senior debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but had limited playtime in Euro 2016. Milner, who also has the record for the most caps as an England Under-21 player with 46, scored his only international goal in 2014. The player has stepped down, expressing support for Sam Allardyce and the team's future.

Marcy Smith and her family narrowly escaped a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, thanks to her son David, who noticed the flames while on FaceTime with his father. The fire, caused by burning rubbish in the wood stove, quickly engulfed the house, killing their pets. The family escaped with only their pyjamas on, and the community has since supported them with donations. Marcy Smith credits David for saving their lives.

The energy drinks company is considering a £200m offer for Premier League club West Ham, which was valued at £105m when Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010. They now own over 85% of the club. West Ham has also been linked with Qatari and Chinese takeovers since moving to the London Stadium. Sullivan and Gold have considered selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but intend to pass ownership to their children.

At a non-Oscar award ceremony in Los Angeles, The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, with Shailene Woodley winning best female performance and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, while Channing Tatum and Meryl Streep won best comedic and best villain, respectively. Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award, and clips from upcoming films were showcased. The event also served as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters.

The Dons loaned 21-year-old Smith to United, where he scored five goals this season. Smith, a Scotland Under-21 cap, made his debut for Aberdeen in 2012 and scored four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren's boss, Jack Ross, praised Smith as a good, mature player and a valuable addition to the team's attacking options. St Mirren will host Falkirk in an upcoming match.

Northumberland County Council plans to use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily for the next four months due to warmer weather. Additional staff will repair damaged drainage systems and clear gutters of debris.

The incident occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland in December 2016, where six Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. The workers were not initially provided with proper personal protective equipment (PPE). Although the exposure level was below the reportable limit, EnQuest informed the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) and took additional precautionary measures after an investigation. The workers, concerned about potential long-term health effects, are undergoing blood tests. The incident raised questions about the duty of care and transparency in handling safety issues in the offshore industry.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007 for $650,000. The sculpture, believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India, was part of a collection of 30 objects bought from the dealer. The ACM decided to return the sculpture after discussions with the Indian government and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), following a 2012 court case against the dealer for trafficking antiquities. The museum plans to take legal action to recover the cost of the sculpture due to the alleged fraud.

A 4.8 magnitude earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with aftershocks felt in Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but power and phone lines were down in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy is prone to earthquakes, and the country is still recovering from a deadly 2009 quake in L'Aquila. Six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for providing inaccurate information about the risk of earthquakes before the 2009 disaster.

The passage describes how Austin Grant, a 62-year-old from Sheffield, was initially skeptical about growing fruit in South Yorkshire's climate. However, he eventually saw success as a fruit, still attached to the plant and not ripe enough to eat, grew. He expressed his joy at this achievement.

Rockstar has delayed the release of their open world adventure game until 24 March, originally set for 27 January, to allow for additional testing and polishing. They apologize for the inconvenience and promise the wait will be worthwhile. The company also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before PCs. PC version details include 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor support. Minimum PC specs for the game have been released. Grand Theft Auto V was the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in three days upon its 2013 release.

The 76-year-old artist won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19), which depicts a leper squint in medieval churches. The painting, which is part of a series, is about 7ft in height and was chosen for the competition due to its size and familiarity to the artist. The prize money will be used to purchase materials for future work. The biennial award, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit newspaper offices in Turkey, supporting the AK Party and President Erdogan, were attacked simultaneously by four masked assailants early Thursday. No casualties were reported, but windows were shattered and bullet casings were found at both locations. The police are currently searching for the attackers, and no group has claimed responsibility yet.

A 24-year-old player, under contract with the Stags, is set to join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer after spending the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. The player, a former Burton player, will officially join the Mariners on 1 January, marking Bignot's first signing for the team.

The passage discusses Arsene Wenger's comments on England manager Sam Allardyce's successor, Gareth Southgate, and Wenger's own future. Southgate, who has had mixed results with England, is seen as a good observer and has upcoming matches to prove his worth. Wenger, whose contract is up in the summer, is focused on his current job despite rumors linking him to the England position. Wenger also addresses the contract situations of Hector Bellerin, who is expected to stay with Arsenal, and Aaron Ramsey, who is recovering from an injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police is conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats. The RMT union had claimed some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will see services return to operator Serco Northlink from Seatruck, which argued the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap, but Seatruck declined. The new arrangements will ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage.

Ken Dickie died after a confrontation with Jamie Mitchell, 35, who had intervened in an argument between Dickie and Mitchell's mother, Samantha. The incident occurred at a park in Poole, and Mitchell had pleaded guilty to common assault. Both Mitchell and his mother admitted to lying about the events to the police, and they will be sentenced on 6 February.

Songwriter Rod Temperton, known for hits like Off The Wall and Baby Be Mine for Michael Jackson and Boogie Nights for Heatwave, has died at 66 after a short battle with cancer. Born in Cleethorpes, Temperton started his career in the 1970s as a keyboardist for disco group Heatwave before writing for Michael Jackson. His songs contributed to Jackson's albums Off The Wall and Thriller, which became the best-selling album of all time in the US. Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. He was nicknamed The Invisible Man due to his low profile.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon. The team, which also includes researchers from the universities of Exeter and Reading, and Brazil's SÃ£o Paulo, BelÃ©m, found ditched enclosures concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest. The function of these sites, known as "geoglyphs," is still unclear, but they are thought to have been used sporadically for ritual gatherings. The research indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems but were influenced by human activity, with evidence of ancient "agroforestry" practices that may have shaped the biodiversity of the region.

The Australian tennis player, Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey in straight sets to advance to the second round of a tournament. Despite his success, including winning the Japan Open, Kyrgios expressed fatigue and lack of motivation during the match, attributing it to poor sleep and traveling for the event. He previously faced criticism for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters the previous year.

The passage discusses the call for the Welsh government to extend the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccination program to protect against head and neck cancers, in addition to cervical cancer. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine, but charities and researchers are urging the government to also vaccinate boys. They argue that the number of head and neck cancer cases are increasing, with three-quarters of those affected being men and the average age being 55. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School student, was battling a rare blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He attended his school prom in his honor but had to leave early due to feeling unwell. Jak had been documenting his life and treatment on social media through "Jak's Journey." He received support from many, including football players and the cast of the musical Wicked. Despite his condition worsening, Jak remained positive and continued to inspire others. He passed away shortly after his prom, surrounded by family and friends. A special football match is being held to raise funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research in his honor.

In a low-scoring game, Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 with a late goal by El Said, set up by Mohamed Salah. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside. Egypt will face Ghana next, while Uganda will play Mali. The match had several fouls and offside calls, with Egypt having a shot saved and a free kick in the defensive half. Substitutions were made for both teams.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a potential new railway station. The decision is based on a study by Network Rail and follows the town's designation as a new town in 1961. The proposed station would offer two direct trains to Liverpool per hour and is expected to improve connectivity and allow for future expansion. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station.
A man in his late 40s was arrested during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne, which was found to be an elaborate grow house with plants.

A 28-year-old German-Kurdish woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, was found with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She was attacked by her 38-year-old ex-partner, also of Kurdish origin, who later surrendered to authorities. The woman underwent an emergency operation and was transferred to a specialist clinic. The motive for the attack is still unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.

The study by Cass Business School, the University of Warwick, and the University of Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The research, which analyzed 4,600 full-time and part-time workers, debunked the "reticent female" theory and found that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study also found no evidence that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase due to concerns about upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The researchers concluded that there may be an element of pure discrimination against women in the workplace. The study also found that women and men under 40 both asked for and received pay rises at the same rate, suggesting that negotiating behavior may be changing.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for years but has found no suitable land due to size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants. The council has spent most of its budget on investigating potential sites. With the two remaining cemeteries expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, only the reopening of family plots, reserved plots, and ash interments will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19-22 July, will offer an augmented reality app for visitors. The app provides online access to festival information, videos, and interviews with performers like The Waterboys and Imelda May. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan states the app will enhance the festival experience and allow global interaction, with updates and ticket purchasing options available.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, despite having no significant underlying health issues. The horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. Although he had a history of overheating, it is concluded that his death was caused by a rare haemorrhage, not his previous condition.

A 34-year-old woman, Davina, is sentenced to a male prison for raping a 15-year-old girl in 2004 after meeting the victim in a Portsmouth garage. The victim tried to stop the attack, but her friends were asleep. Davina denied the charge, and the court heard that the victim had not made any physical changes or taken medication. The case was described as unusual and difficult by Judge Ian Pearson.

The Serbian tennis team lost to Brazilian pair Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, following Novak Djokovic's defeat by Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, a 12-time Grand Slam winner, had previously suffered a surprising loss at Wimbledon and had won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics. The summary also mentions a BBC Sport newsletter subscription for sports news and features.

The Carrbridge log-carving competition in the Cairngorms will have over 20 participants from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the US. Competitors must use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Pete Bowsher from Moffat, last year's winner, will defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, is nearing a return to the field after a serious foot injury in September. He is currently in pre-season training and aims to be fit for the Six Nations in February. Wales' Six Nations campaign starts on February 7 against Ireland. Webb, who has 16 caps for Wales, has renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region club.

The incident involved two men attempting to smuggle 58lb of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco, which was intercepted by US border agents near Sumas, Washington. One man fled after firing a weapon, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested. Canadian and US police searched for the fugitive, leading to the arrest of Nathan Hall, who was found with the drugs and a California driver's license with William Nickerson's name but Nathan Hall's picture. Kali Henifin and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their involvement in the smuggling operation. The three defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is known for smuggling activities.

The NSPCC's Childline service counselled over 4,500 children in the past year for online abuse, a significant increase from 2,400 in 2011-12. Children as young as seven have reported being tormented and scared to go to school due to online trolls. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasized the need for adult intervention and schools to take the issue seriously. The Anti Bullying Alliance is coordinating efforts to combat the problem during Anti-Bullying Week. A young person shared their experience of being told to commit suicide online, highlighting the emotional distress caused by cyberbullying. Advice from young people on dealing with bullying includes seeking help from adults and not facing the issue alone.

The Israeli government has postponed a vote on new settlement homes in East Jerusalem following a request from Prime Minister Netanyahu's office. This decision comes amid tensions with the US after the UN Security Council passed a resolution against settlement construction, which Israel considers illegal under international law. The postponement aims to avoid further straining relations with Washington before US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas sees the UN resolution as a step towards ending the occupation and a peace conference in France.

The passage discusses the BBC interview with Prince William, where he praises Queen Elizabeth II as a guiding example of a good monarch on the eve of her 90th birthday. A picture of the Queen with Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George has been released for stamp commemorations. The Queen and Prince Philip will participate in various events, including unveiling a plaque for The Queen's Walkway and lighting a beacon. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle. Prince William discusses his commitment to royal duty and his approach to criticism in the interview. The BBC has been criticized by Republic for its coverage of the Queen's birthday celebrations.

In a match between League Two side Cheltenham Town and Premier League side West Ham United, the latter dominated with two goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew before half-time. Cheltenham had some chances but failed to score, with the best moment being Harry Pell's volley. West Ham could have won by a greater margin, but Cheltenham's Robins captain Kyle Storer and keeper Jonathan Flatt made crucial saves. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup. The match ended 2-0 in favor of West Ham.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when 46-year-old Andreas Werner failed to spot him while turning his VW Transporter. Werner, from Leipzig, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not seek jail time for Werner, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist, attempted to return to the UK after spending time in Syria as a fighter for the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. He was active online, sharing propaganda and recruitment material. Upon his return, he faked his death and was arrested at the border. Khawaja is facing a possible life imprisonment for his involvement in the Syrian conflict, and his intentions for returning to the UK remain unclear. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, who helped him return, pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Jackson, a 22-year-old footballer, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season. He has now signed with Barnsley as their third new player for the upcoming season. Jackson previously turned down a contract offer from Wrexham. The news was announced by caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom.

A container believed to have been lost from the MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather in May is thought to have washed up on the Cornish coast, including Poldhu Cove, posing a risk to wildlife. The bottles, containing 'Vanish' detergent, have been leaking and are being cleared away by National Trust volunteers. Nearby coves have also been affected, and authorities are monitoring the situation. The public is advised to keep a safe distance from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

The A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness experienced a crash at around 14:00, resulting in minor injuries for several people. The road was closed with diversions set up through the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is still investigating the incident.

Dervite, a French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season for Wanderers, contributing to their second-place finish in League One and promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite recently signed a new contract with Bolton, following other players like David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The Lib Dem Lord Oates and Labour's Baroness Smith clashed over their parties' approaches to Brexit and cooperation in the Lords. The two parties had previously worked together to challenge the government on EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approval, but disagreements arose when MPs rejected those amendments. Labour accused the Lib Dems of creating false hope, while the Lib Dems criticized Labour for supporting the government's Brexit plans. Despite past alliances on various issues, tensions remain between the two parties.

In the current election, defence is a low priority for political parties, with defence spending falling behind other concerns like the economy, NHS, and immigration. The UK has reduced its armed forces and faces capability gaps, with defence spending falling to sixth place globally. The military is concerned about further cuts, with the Conservatives and UKIP committed to renewing Trident and maintaining defence spending, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats have different approaches to the nuclear deterrent. The UK's new aircraft carriers may face crew shortages and reduced equipment, highlighting the challenges of maintaining a strong military presence.

The Spanish champions Barcelona insisted they had not committed any offence regarding the transfer of Neymar from Santos. The club made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover potential misinterpretations of Neymar's contract. Barcelona previously paid £48.6m for Neymar, with additional costs bringing the total to £106.8m. Amidst accusations of tax-related crimes, the club maintains its innocence and believes the original tax payment was in line with fiscal obligations. A Spanish judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, was killed when a van he was in was hit by a car driving the wrong way on the motorway. The driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, also died. Luciw's family believes older drivers should have regular driving tests to ensure road safety. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licenses every three years through a self-assessment form, but no medical or driving test is required. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) states there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age, as evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older people to continue driving safely for as long as possible.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of implants used to treat incontinence, following reports of debilitating side effects in women. Two patients quit a review group in protest over a perceived diluted report. Independent expert Alison Britton will now examine the final report's process and conclusions. The report suggested that procedures should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse, and patients should be given a range of treatments to make informed decisions. Despite calls for a complete ban, the recommendations will be implemented, as the power to ban lies with the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members and expressed disappointment at not achieving consensus. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, with over 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Muir broke McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan questioned if Muir's race met all criteria for record-breaking attempts, but British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to run faster and win world medals. Muir previously broke her own British 1500m record and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won on Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou, with Astier Nicolas of France taking silver and Phillip Dutton of America bronze. William Fox-Pitt of GB finished 12th after a strong final show-jumping phase, but earlier penalties in the cross-country phase hindered his medal chances. Jonty Evans of Ireland placed ninth. The passage also mentions fan engagement activities during the Rio Olympics and a guide to equestrian sports.

In a tense and dramatic match, British tennis player Murray defeated Italian Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 to advance to the fourth round of a tournament for the 11th time. Fognini had five set points but Murray won five consecutive games to secure his spot. Murray will face Frenchman Benoit Paire next. The match was played under challenging conditions as it got dark, and Murray expressed relief at finishing the match in four sets. Despite some ups and downs, Murray was satisfied with his performance and looks forward to the next round.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, following a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar, with alcohol served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge noted O'Neill's "appalling record" and imposed fines of £3,000 and £1,000 on O'Neill and Thomas, respectively.

In his speech launching the Ulster Unionist party's manifesto, Mike Nesbitt emphasized the need for partnership over domination and expressed a desire for the election to be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal. He addressed the controversy surrounding his comments about transferring votes to the SDLP, stating he had no regrets and that his words were meant to address the future of Stormont. The party's manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', includes proposals for tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and mitigating the impact of Brexit. Nesbitt also called for a cleanup of Stormont, citing incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption as key issues.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed a motion to align Northern Ireland with England and Wales regarding automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. The law, known as 'Turing's Law', will allow posthumous pardons and enable living convicts to apply for a pardon. The motion, which is expected to have the same provisions as in England and Wales, will be presented for assembly approval and aims to provide equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland. The legislative consent motion will be brought in as soon as possible.

A 23-year-old runner from Kinross, Muir, broke the Scottish 1500m record held by Yvonne Murray since 1994, finishing second in a race in 4:19.12, behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. Muir now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records and aims to secure an Olympic place in Rio. She balances her training with veterinary studies, recently completing her fourth year.
The passage presents a list of 26 beaches in Scotland that are ranked as the best in terms of water quality.

The Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that the Russian state likely sponsored the murder of ex-KGB agent Alexander Litvinenko, with suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi having no personal motive. Litvinenko was poisoned with polonium-210 in 2006, and the evidence suggests Russian state involvement, though not necessarily direct orders from President Putin. Litvinenko had defected to the UK in 2000 and made personal attacks on Putin. The public risk from polonium radiation exposure remains unknown, and the suspects left a trail of polonium behind. Extradition attempts have failed, and the suspects remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, 26, will captain the Australian Twenty20 team and lead the one-day side, with David Warner, 28, as his vice-captain. Smith has already captained the team in three Tests against India and has played in 32 Tests for his country. The decision to appoint Smith as captain comes after Michael Clarke's retirement. The pair will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

The passage discusses Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron's views on LGBT rights. Although he refused to directly comment on whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, he expressed his passion for LGBT-plus rights and promised to prioritize equal marriage rights and transgender marital rights if he remains leader. He previously voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties, but did not elaborate on these concerns. He supports equal access under law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

Accord Healthcare plans to use the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, creating job opportunities for many of the 450 former Sanofi employees. The investment is expected to positively impact the local economy and strengthen the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company with over 130 products distributed to 60 countries.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving the local authority due to contract end, voluntary redundancy, and early retirement. Stephen Flynn criticizes the council for losing senior staff and anticipates more departures. Ellis served as interim director of corporate governance and deputy chief executive, Monaghan led the chief executive's office, and Sutherland managed human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott commends their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider experienced a crash at this year's TT and faced mechanical issues with the Fireblade bike. Initially considering quitting road racing, he later clarified that he would not participate in any more road racing on Hondas for the remainder of the year. He did not race at the North West 200 and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. The rider expressed dissatisfaction with the TT and his role as a test rider, and after determining the bike would not be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, the team decided to withdraw him from the event. He now wishes to focus on racing classics and unique events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost the presidential poll last month and key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna. The APC made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than previous years. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader after being in power for 16 years.

The US-based environmental lobby group Mighty has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of ignoring unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to the haze in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Both companies reject the allegations. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy. However, Mighty claims Olam has created a market for rogue palm oil companies. Temasek, as Olam's majority stakeholder, could be linked to the haze if the allegations are proven. The palm oil industry is often accused of unfair labor practices, deforestation, and burning plantations. The report also raises concerns about Olam's activities in Gabon, where it is accused of clearing forests for palm oil plantations. Olam denies the allegations and claims its partnerships in Gabon are responsible and transparent.
The passage discusses a restaurant that started serving puppy platters on 27 August 2016, following a new law permitting dogs to dine at restaurants outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is uncertain to play due to a knee issue, while David Nugent may return to action after a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield is seeking a recall following a bench appearance where he scored a late goal.

The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) has lifted the ban on YouTube, following the launch of a Pakistan-specific version by Google. Internet service providers have been directed to restore access to YouTube. The Pakistan government and Google have established a process for the PTA to request the removal of offensive content. However, YouTube has stated that it will only remove content that violates its community guidelines. The ban was initially imposed in 2012 due to the upload of a controversial film. Some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms of the agreement between Google and the Pakistani government.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, as is Gianni Infantino, a presidential candidate. Scala stepped aside in the 2015 elections due to shared nationality with candidate Sepp Blatter. LFA boss Musa Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala doesn't withdraw, citing a potential conflict of interest. Scala's spokesperson argues no such conflict exists. Bility, previously denied election participation, supports Prince Ali and criticizes the current electoral process. Five candidates, including Infantino and Champagne, are vying to replace Blatter in the upcoming election.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday, and a forensic search has been conducted. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham stated that a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source is the likely cause. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia was initially expelled from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations for complaints against the Confederation of African Football (CAF), but later apologized and was reinstated. Morocco faced a ban on participation in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw, which was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). Morocco was initially punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, but the fine was reduced by CAS. Equatorial Guinea replaced Morocco as the 2015 host. Tunisia had a contentious quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea, which led to a dispute with CAF. However, after a meeting with CAF President Issa Hayatou, Tunisia was able to reconcile with CAF and participate in the 2017 Nations Cup. Tunisia and Morocco are in Groups A and F, respectively, in the 2017 draw.

The passage describes a post-match incident at the Etihad Stadium where Chelsea won 3-1 against City. Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho of City were sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for violent conduct and Fernandinho a three-match ban for his involvement in the ensuing scuffle. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. City manager Pep Guardiola has apologized for the incident. Both teams have until December 8th to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses the establishment of additional cancer diagnostic centers in Wales to address the high number of late-stage cancer diagnoses. The Welsh Government plans to open six new centers, including one in the Cwm Taf area, to improve early diagnosis rates. Currently, only 35% of patients in Cwm Taf with clear symptoms receive an early diagnosis. The initiative aims to provide more accessible diagnostic services, with the goal of increasing early diagnosis rates and improving patient outcomes. The success of the pilot program in the Cwm Cynon area will determine the expansion of the service.

In a cricket match at Old Trafford, England won with a day to spare, setting up their second largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. England's Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his impressive scoring and fielding. Pakistan struggled with their batting, only lasting 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second. England coach Trevor Bayliss praised Root's performance, while former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott predicted a tight series. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment with the team's performance and called for improvement.

Warren Gatland leads the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley as interim coach. Forwards coach McBryde takes head coach responsibilities for the third time, leading Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and provide opportunities for development in different environments.

Hull City secured a 2-1 victory against Southampton, ending a six-game losing streak and their first win in the league since 20 August. The win was sparked by a quick-fire double from Hull in the second half, following Charlie Austin's early penalty for Southampton. Hull's top scorer, Robert Snodgrass, returned from injury to make a significant impact, scoring his fourth league goal of the season and providing an assist for Michael Dawson. Hull's goalkeeper, David Marshall, made crucial saves throughout the match, while Southampton struggled to maintain their early lead. The win for Hull came just before the international break, with the team now having three or four injuries to contend with.

A motorcyclist was killed in a crash with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at 14:15 BST. The local motorcyclist's details have not been released, while the tractor driver was unharmed. The road was closed between the B1192 and A158 junctions, and witnesses are being sought by the Lincolnshire Police.

The President of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings to end political turmoil before early elections in June. This decision faced condemnation from the opposition and EU officials. The crisis began with recordings suggesting ministers' involvement in vote-rigging and murder cover-ups. The opposition accuses the government of corruption and wiretapping, while the government accuses the opposition of destabilizing the country. The EU Enlargement Commissioner warned that the President's actions risk Macedonia's EU membership aspirations.

Swansea City, after sacking Bob Bradley, has appointed Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams to lead the team in the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club is looking to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement, the former Derby manager, as the preferred choice. Swansea City, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, has experienced a decline since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis believes the team has lost its way and the 'Swansea Way' has been diluted. Despite this, he thinks the current squad is good enough to stay up in the Premier League.

The Daggers, in League Two, required a win to maintain their survival hopes but lost to Dagenham & Redbridge, who scored the winning goal through Armand Gnanduillet. This defeat jeopardized the Daggers' play-off chances and occurred shortly after the dismissal of their player-manager Kevin Nolan. Dagenham, managed by John Still, will return to the National League after being relegated, despite having reached the Football League for the first time in 2007. The Daggers struggle with a poor goal difference and defensive issues, while Dagenham faces challenges in attack, with Jamie Cureton scoring nine goals this season. Leyton Orient, now led by interim manager Andy Hessenthaler, remains two points away from play-off contention, emphasizing the need for professionalism and fan support. John Still criticized his team's lack of organization and discipline in the first half, contributing to their loss.

The passage discusses the return of former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard to his old club as a youth coach in February, marking his first job after retirement. Gerrard had a conversation with Klopp, who expressed confidence in Gerrard's future as a manager, given his playing experience and willingness to learn. Gerrard, who had a successful 19-year career with Liverpool, had been linked to a managerial role at MK Dons but felt it was too soon. He is also working towards his UEFA A coaching license, necessary for managing in the Premier League.

In the passage, McManus scored the opening goal and later secured another, while Ross Forbes and Denny Johnstone also contributed to the scoreline. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa, but ultimately Morton achieved a comfortable win.

Ofsted discovered children being taught in unsanitary conditions in three unregistered schools in Birmingham, leading to their closure. Inspectors found the conditions shocking, and investigations are ongoing into the owners for suspected illegal operation. Sir Michael Wilshaw warns these cases may be just the beginning, with concerns about child abuse and radicalization. The government is considering more regulations for places providing education for over 6-8 hours a week, and a team of inspectors has been funded to investigate illegal schools. The issue is not limited to Muslim communities, as all religious groups could be subject to scrutiny. The Education Secretary has called for prosecutions against unregistered schools and is seeking public input on further regulations.

Lilliard Gin is a new gin distillery located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, Scotland. It is the first in the region since 1837 and aims to showcase local flavors and botanicals from the Teviot valley. The distillery, led by Kate Macinnes, is one of the smallest in the UK and fits into a cowshed. The gin is named after a local legend, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery is in line with the Scottish Borders Brewery's ethos of local sourcing.

Harry Whitlam was fatally hit by a vehicle reversed by Gary Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit, at Swithens Farm in Rothwell, Leeds, in August 2013. The incident occurred on private land, leading to Green being prosecuted under health and safety legislation. He was sentenced to 16 months in prison for failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her grief and called for stricter measures against drunk driving.

The Uruguay striker, Luis Suarez, can now train and play in friendly matches after his four-month ban was partially lifted. He will join Barcelona's first team training and have a public presentation as a new player. Suarez still has to serve the remaining eight games of his ban in competitive international games, and his competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October. He will be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) upheld most of Fifa's sanctions but found preventing Suarez from any football activity excessive. His lawyers argued that the ban was too strong and misapplied Fifa's rules. Suarez has apologized for the incident, and his legal team claimed the appeal was a success.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a challenging competition, where participants had to tackle a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. The event allowed all combinations of competitors, and the winners will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK's paper car tax disc system will be replaced with an electronic system in October 2014, allowing for monthly direct debit payments. This change, announced by Chancellor George Osborne, has raised concerns about the future of some of the 5,000 workers at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA). In response to these concerns, Minister Stephen Hammond assured that job losses would be minimized through redeployment to other areas of the business, with changes to job roles and training on new processes. This response has been welcomed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, who sees the advantages of the new system and is pleased with the minister's commitment to redeployment rather than redundancies.

The passage discusses Hungary's defiance against the EU regarding its domestic policies. Hungary has passed laws that the EU objects to, including strict controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, and a higher education law that could shut down the Central European University. Hungary has received support from Poland, which would veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU requires unanimous approval for actions like stripping a member country of its voting rights. Hungary's government is under pressure to withdraw these laws, with the EU considering action if there are no positive changes. The Central European University, founded by George Soros, is at risk due to the higher education law.

Emma Watson is cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston in the 2017 live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. Kevin Kline plays Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts. The film, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios and is set for release on March 17, 2017.

Columnist Adrian Gill, known for his work at the Sunday Times and his battle with multiple cancers, passed away recently. Described as a "giant among journalists," Gill was celebrated for his wit, dazzling writing, and compassionate intelligence. He was also known for his controversial articles and personal struggles with dyslexia. Gill's final column, about coming to terms with his diagnosis, was published posthumously.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator, suffering severe injuries including a brain injury. The incident occurred while he was performing in a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol unrelated to Nazism. The Russian embassy is investigating the attack, which local press reports claim involved a Russian diplomat, but the embassy states the reports are distorted. Sukhbaatar's father emphasized the swastika's cultural significance in Mongolia, and the musician's representatives denied claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the performance. The suspect, a Russian diplomat, has not been arrested due to the non-serious nature of his injuries, according to a police spokesman.

The passage describes a protest by Plane Stupid action group campaigners against airport expansion plans. They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area, and will face court on 19 August. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on a Monday, leading to a review of airport security by the Metropolitan Police.

In a first-class cricket match in the Welsh capital, Nick Selman scored a dominant 101 runs for Glamorgan, with seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles taking regular wickets. Gloucestershire struggled to keep up, with Aneurin Donald scoring 36 runs. Glamorgan secured a consolation bonus point with the help of Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten. Glamorgan's Michael Hogan led the team for the first time due to Jacques Rudolph's absence. Selman expressed satisfaction with his performance after a series of low scores, while Matt Taylor from Gloucestershire highlighted the challenging conditions for batsmen and the opportunities for bowlers. The match ended with Gloucestershire in a survival mode.

Craig Hughes, 33, was arrested after making online threats to ambush and shoot police officers at the Dee Estuary, as reported to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted two charges in Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Hughes, who was drunk during the threats, had a previous firearm conviction in 2009. He claimed not to intend to kill himself or the officers and was on bail for firearms offences, which he was later cleared of. The Hope Line centre provides support and counselling to those in need.

Yorkshire, with a record of 8-2, collapsed from 255-7 to 236 all out after losing key wickets in a burst from Stuart Meaker. Despite a strong partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes, Yorkshire fell short in their chase against Surrey. Surrey's Gareth Batty praised his team's bowling and fielding, while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment in his team's failure to chase down the target, despite having played well in the season.

A 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, faced water ingress issues and contacted Holyhead coastguards. The boat's pump couldn't handle the water, leading the RNLI lifeboat crew to provide a pump and tow the vessel to Holyhead.

The passage discusses Scottish middle distance runner Laura Muir, who won a 5,000m race at the World Athletics Championships but will miss the Commonwealths due to her veterinary medicine exams in May. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, expressed disappointment at missing the event but emphasized the importance of her degree. She believes she has at least two more Olympics in her and targets the World Indoor Championships in March.

Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's struggles in the current season, highlighting their inability to repeat last season's title challenge. He believes Liverpool is far from the required level to compete for the title and suggests that securing a top-four finish would be a success for manager Brendan Rodgers. Savage criticizes Rodgers' transfer decisions, particularly in the forward positions, and notes that the team lacks the intensity and work-rate they displayed last season. He also points out issues with set-pieces and the team's defensive organization. Despite these challenges, Savage believes Steven Gerrard remains an important player for Liverpool and can continue to contribute in a defensive midfield role. He also emphasizes Gerrard's mental strength and determination to overcome recent setbacks.

A £45m educational facility, including primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre, is planned for Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock. The East Ayrshire Council intends to name the campus after the late writer William McIlvanney, a Kilmarnock native, in recognition of his passion for education. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," was a celebrated author, poet, journalist, and broadcaster who contributed significantly to Scotland's cultural and political life.

The town near a swimming pool was evacuated due to a sea mine spotted on Monday, thought to be from the 1940s or 1950s. An exclusion zone was established on land and at sea, affecting three streets and a 500m radius around the mine. Residents were advised to stay indoors and small boat owners to avoid sailing. Ferry services were disrupted. The evacuation was precautionary, with no immediate danger to the community. The mine's explosive content could not be determined, so it was moved to a safer location before being dealt with. The council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation.

The passage discusses the UK's funding cuts for several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, with cycling also experiencing a significant reduction. Badminton, despite achieving a bronze medal in Rio, lost its funding, causing concern for the sport's future. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo, with a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. UK Sport emphasizes the need to prioritize funding to protect and enhance medal potential. Some sports, like basketball, handball, and volleyball, have had their funding withdrawn in previous years, with UK Sport stating that responsibility for funding their performance development lies with other funding bodies. The funding for five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The planning board approved the project, stating the old buildings were no longer functional and the development would benefit tourism and provide improved living for older residents. Despite objections from English Heritage and local residents, the council voted in favor of the project, which will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments.

Off-duty soldier Pte Matthew Boyd was punched and beaten by Jake Vallely in Brecon, resulting in his death. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. CCTV footage showed the attack and Vallely dragging Boyd's body away. The court heard Vallely had been drinking heavily and boasting about being the "hardest man in Brecon". A family tribute described Boyd as a loving, caring, and promising soldier whose life was tragically cut short.

Andrew Travers resigned from his position as chief executive of Barnet Council following an error that led to voters being turned away from polling stations due to their names missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to review the incident and the council's arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum in June. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over while longer-term arrangements are made. The council has apologized for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents.

In a football match summary, Josh Gillies scored for Gateshead with a free-kick, and Wrexham equalized before half-time through Sean Newton. Gateshead took the lead with a goal by Ryan Bowman, assisted by Craig Baxter. Gateshead coach Malcolm Crosby praised his team's improvement in the second half, while Wrexham coach Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's performance, particularly in the second half. The match ended 2-1 in favor of Gateshead. The summary includes key events such as goals, substitutions, and free-kicks, reflecting the match's dynamic nature and the coaches' perspectives.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan and Mozambique are at the bottom of the list. The report was last updated on 1 October 2014.

The passage discusses the OneWeb project, which aims to create a network of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband links, with a focus on connecting schools. Airbus is adapting its manufacturing process to produce satellites at high volumes and low costs, using assembly line methods similar to car and plane factories. The first assembly line has been established in Toulouse, France, with two more planned in Florida. The project requires a significant number of rocket launches to establish the constellation, with a goal of having nearly 300 satellites in orbit by the end of 2020. OneWeb, a global company registered in the UK, is working on debris mitigation strategies to address concerns about space junk. The new manufacturing approach may disrupt the satellite industry, but some specialized satellites will still require custom production.

The passage discusses the impact of the UK government's spending review on Scotland's public expenditure. Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney claims that the review places "unprecedented pressure" on Scotland's budget, with cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 and more cuts expected until 2020. Despite having £390m more in spending next year, the Scottish government argues that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than in 2010-11. Swinney insists that schools, hospitals, and police services in Scotland will not be sacrificed to austerity. A spokesperson for the UK government's Scotland Office argues that the Scottish government should focus on its new powers rather than complaining. Labour's public services spokeswoman Jackie Baillie criticizes Swinney's approach and calls for a long-term budget to address austerity.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families when accessing suitable toilet facilities in public spaces. Ordinary accessible toilets are not enough for those who need two carers or a hoist to transfer. Changing Places toilets, with enhanced facilities and more space, are recommended for larger buildings, but are not yet compulsory. Campaigners, including parents of disabled children, are calling for changes in building regulations to make Changing Places guidelines mandatory. The lack of appropriate facilities can cause stress, guilt, and feelings of exclusion for disabled individuals and their families. Some businesses have already installed Changing Places toilets, recognizing the importance of inclusivity for all customers.

A group of Italian consumer organizations filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the company of imposing excessive rents and fees on franchisees. McDonald's responded by emphasizing its commitment to supporting franchisees through risk and reward sharing. The Service Employees International Union and European unions back the complaint, claiming McDonald's market dominance negatively impacts franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will review the complaint and potentially launch an investigation. The consumer organizations argue that franchisees are bound by long contracts and above-market leases, leading to limited consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to company-owned ones. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, generating $9.27bn in global franchised revenues in 2014.

A #prayforjosh poster appeared in Holywood to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The social media campaign began with a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works. The campaign went viral, and a mystery donor paid for a large billboard displaying the hashtag. Josh's classmates and people worldwide have been showing support for him on Twitter.

The UK government plans to close Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Wales, as part of a military building shake-up and regiment resettlement. Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies strongly condemned the decision, calling it abhorrent and disrespectful to the barracks' long history. Davies plans to launch a petition against the closure, citing high unemployment rates in the area and potential damage to the local military tourism industry. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, as part of the reorganisation. The closure of Cawdor Barracks, Pembrokeshire, was also confirmed for 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring but expressed concern over the impact on local livelihoods and uncertainty for those affected.

The House of Lords European Union Committee report highlights the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. The industry, which contributes only 0.5% of GDP and employs 12,000 people, may be marginalised in negotiations but should not be. Key issues include the potential need to allow EU boats access to UK waters in exchange for market access, the importance of retaining elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) like scientific-based quotas, and the possibility of different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these challenges, some in the industry are optimistic about the potential for a more sustainable and equitable fishing industry post-Brexit.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked documents revealing the US National Security Agency's (NSA) mass surveillance programs. These programs, such as Prism, allow access to individual chat logs, voice traffic, file transfers, social networking data, and phone records from major technology companies. The US government confirmed requesting phone records from Verizon. The NSA claims these operations are crucial for national security. The legality and extent of these surveillance programs are debated, with concerns about privacy and the potential for abuse. The data collected is often stored in the US, subject to US law, raising concerns about the privacy of non-US citizens. The involvement of other governments, such as the UK's GCHQ, is unclear. The existence of these programs confirms privacy concerns and highlights the tension between privacy and security in the digital age.

The venture, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, is focused on AI research with a positive human impact, free from financial obligations. Some experts warn AI could threaten humanity, while others believe the risk is remote. OpenAI aims to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity, and distribute AI as broadly as possible. Only a small portion of the $1bn pledged will be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, a bomb attack survivor from Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch in Doncaster on 26 June, receiving thousands of Facebook friend requests, which are limited to 5,000 per profile. His story of resilience and humor has garnered significant support, leading to increased mail, emails, and requests for torch appearances. Despite the Facebook limit, his mother suggests he could create a public page or use the subscribe feature. Parkinson, who spends 12 hours a day in rehab, is also a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits and raises funds for military charities.

In 2011, the US poverty rate was 15%, with 46.2 million people in poverty, and the real median household income decreased by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021, and income inequality rose by 1.6%, marking the first increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7%. Poverty had reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.

The 25-year-old cricketer Buttler moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013 and signed a new deal until 2019. He is a short-format specialist, having scored England's three fastest ODI centuries. Ashley Giles, cricket director and head coach, praises Buttler's talent, experience, and positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler, who plays for Mumbai Indians in the Indian Premier League, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are up for sale, with interested parties finalizing bids for potential purchase and repurposing. The UK government aims to award at least one ship to a UK recycler to assess the industry's capacity. There are suggestions to repurpose the ships as reefs or diving attractions to generate tourism revenue. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers. The Type 22 frigates were originally designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful surface combatants with various weapons systems and excellent command and control facilities.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced racial and political tensions, leading to four coups, including a 2000 coup that held the first ethnic Indian prime minister hostage. These events have negatively impacted the economy, particularly the tourism industry, and Fiji's international reputation. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the latter group experiencing a decline due to coups and agitation. Fiji's economy relies on sugar and tourism, but it has persistent trade and budget deficits. In 2012, Fiji agreed to hold free elections, leading to its reinstatement in the Commonwealth.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad of Syria stated that Syria is working to comply with the destruction of its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline and facing attacks on shipments by terrorist groups. He defended the Syrian government's actions in Aleppo and accused the US of supporting terrorists. The Syrian government denied rebels' control of Aleppo's central prison, while reports conflict on the prison's status. The US expressed concern over the slow progress of the UN-backed plan to remove Syria's chemical weapons, with a new deadline set for March 1st. The OPCW acknowledged security concerns have slowed the process.
