The Lives of Others by Mukherjee is the 5/2 favourite to win the 46th Booker Prize, which is open to all authors writing in English. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and an Australian. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The Lives of Others focuses on secrets and rivalries within a family in 1960s Calcutta, while other shortlisted novels cover topics such as atheism, a love story set during World War II, and a futuristic love story. The best-selling book on the shortlist is We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves by Fowler, with over 55,000 copies sold.

A man is appealing against a ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in media reports in England and Wales. The UK Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction is in place until the hearing concludes. The man, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is known as PJS and is involved in a case regarding alleged extra-marital activities. The Sun on Sunday wishes to publish details of the allegations, but PJS argues for his right to privacy. The Court of Appeal judges previously ruled in favor of PJS, but the ban was challenged as the story had already been published in other regions and online. The judges stated that due to the widespread nature of the information, a permanent injunction is unlikely to be effective.

Fosse Park, located near M1 junction 21, was purchased in August for £345.5m. The new owners plan to enhance parking, traffic flow, and the appearance of the units. The park is seen as an investment opportunity to improve the gateway from Blaby into the city. The main concerns are parking, congestion, and the quality of common areas and facilities.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" and was subject to review by the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF). The LPF approved the film with a minor edit related to the gay scene, despite homosexual activity being illegal in Malaysia. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification" and a new release date is pending. The decision faced criticism from Malaysians, with some arguing the country bans films with moral values while allowing low-quality local movies.

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated individuals must apply for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) license, which costs £1,000, or face a £20,000 fine. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants often fear eviction and poor property maintenance due to a shortage of affordable homes. Nationally, mandatory licensing applies to houses of three storeys or more with five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, licenses are required for specific areas. The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) aim to prevent a second election by facilitating a minority government, although Fianna Fáil won't support a programme for government. The main disagreement is on water charges and the future of Irish Water. Post-election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, but no majority government was formed and a Taoiseach has not been elected.

The Sorrento, a ship traveling to Valencia, caught fire on a car deck about 27km from Mallorca, leading to the evacuation of passengers onto lifeboats and their subsequent rescue by another ship, the Puglia. Three people were injured, with one seriously hurt, and transported to the hospital by helicopter. The cause of the fire was unclear. Despite initial resistance from the captain, the fire's intensity necessitated a full evacuation. The ship may sink due to the fire. Passengers were expected to return to Palma de Mallorca shortly, with psychologists on standby at the port for counseling. The ship, owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, had sent distress signals at 13:50 local time.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs identified potential double voting cases, with concerns about duplicate registrations, particularly among students. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 2017 election, with 68.7% turnout. Issues with duplicate applications arose after the EU referendum, and the current system lacks a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service. The watchdog suggested clearer information and a verification function to reduce duplicate applications, which are estimated to range between 30% and 70% in different areas. Labour warned against making it harder for young people and students to register to vote.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star University of Nebraska player and NFL athlete, is believed to have committed suicide at age 40. His career was marred by legal issues and violence, leading to a prison sentence for assault. He was in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate and was set to stand trial for the murder. Despite his talents, Phillips struggled with anger and personal demons.

Lance Corporal Derby XXX, a mascot ram of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted for good behavior after eight years, marking the 30th in a lineage dating back to the Indian Mutiny War. Acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment in 1858, he became the Mercian Regiment's mascot in 2007. He joined the regiment in 2014, has an army number, and enjoys rations, holidays during mating season, and public appearances, including switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

The passage describes a thrilling football match where Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory against Borussia Dortmund, moving them closer to the Champions League. Jurgen Klopp, Liverpool's manager, inspired his team to overcome a 2-0 deficit and complete a comeback reminiscent of their 2005 Champions League Final win. The match was filled with emotion, drama, and excitement, with Liverpool fans playing a significant role in motivating the team. The victory has increased Liverpool's confidence and puts them in a strong position in the Europa League, with a potential return to the Champions League on the horizon. Klopp has instilled his identity in the team and has set a high standard for his players to achieve before they can touch the famous "This Is Anfield" sign.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London, where UK's Mr. Davis promised regular updates to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland on Brexit negotiations and proposed monthly meetings for a "two-way information flow." Mr. Russell of Scotland acknowledged the inclusion process but criticized the UK government for lack of clarity on its strategic intentions, especially regarding single market and customs union membership, which is crucial for Scotland's economic prosperity. The Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal regarding Article 50.

The passage describes a detailed examination of 13 cloned sheep, including Daisy, who are part of a study at the University of Nottingham to determine the health and aging process of cloned animals. The sheep, cloned from the same ewe as Dolly the first cloned mammal, are undergoing tests to assess for signs of aging and disease, particularly osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. The study aims to understand if cloned animals age normally or if they experience premature aging due to the cloning process. The results of this research could have significant implications for the future of cloning. The cloned sheep currently appear healthy, despite being near their ninth and tenth birthdays.

The passage discusses a horse race where the unbeaten favorite, trained by John Gosden, won by a length and three quarters against runner-up Vintage Folly. The horse will next race in Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom, where other stablemates Enable and Coronet are contenders. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, while Shutter Speed secured a Musidora win for Gosden and jockey Dettori, who noted the horse's good form despite soft ground. Gosden is considering whether to enter his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes due to concerns about the ground. Shutter Speed is in good order and will aim for the Oaks in France, while Gosden prepares for the Derby with a month's notice. Cracksman may not run in the Dante Stakes due to the short gap before the Derby.

The passage discusses the fluctuating value of the pound against the dollar, euro, and yen due to uncertainty surrounding the UK's potential exit from the EU. The volatility index has reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign claims the pound has returned to its March levels. Investors are nervous due to a decline in the likelihood of a Remain vote and global economic concerns. Polls show a tight race between the Leave and Remain campaigns, increasing uncertainty and volatility in the pound. Hedge funds are betting on a further decline in the pound's value. Asian stock markets have also been affected by Brexit worries. The FTSE 100 initially fell slightly but ended the day down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group experiencing the largest drop. Nigel Farage, a Leave campaigner, argues that a weaker pound could benefit UK exporters, citing a narrowing trade deficit in April.

The Iron are currently in sixth place in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. After a challenging match against Barrow, which extended their unbeaten league run to nine games, Cowley remains positive despite Braintree's three-game losing streak. He acknowledges the difficulty of the journey as a part-time team, but remains committed to embracing and enjoying the challenge.

The passage discusses a shift in planning decision-making from the Planning Service to local councils in Northern Ireland, effective from April 2015. This change will allow elected politicians to make planning decisions, with the aim of democratizing the planning system. However, concerns have been raised about the potential for discrimination and favoritism in planning decisions, as well as the need for transparency and accountability in the process. Critics argue that the new system could lead to a repeat of past discrimination in public housing allocation and close relationships between developers and political parties. Supporters believe the change offers an opportunity for local councils to develop their own community and development plans. The debate also touches on the issue of political donations and the need for transparency in the process.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was found injured with three gunshot wounds, requiring the amputation of her left back leg. The owner, Sarah Nisbett, believes the cat was shot in a housing estate with many children, raising concerns about potential crossfire. The Scottish SPCA and Teenie's owner are calling for the urgent implementation of a licensing system for airguns to prevent such incidents and ensure responsible ownership. Last year, a majority of respondents in a Scottish government consultation opposed the proposed licensing scheme.

Liverpool signs Belgium international Benteke on a long-term contract for £32.5m, making him the Reds' second most expensive signing. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk in 2012. The 24-year-old joins Liverpool to revive the Reds' attack after a lack of goals last season. Liverpool also signs Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino, while Divock Origi returns to the club. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup due to an Achilles tendon injury but returned to action last October, scoring 15 times to help Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, found that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets, with intensive use in 9% of schools where each student has a device. Tablets are more prevalent in academy schools and are expected to increase in schools. However, there is no clear evidence that tablets improve academic performance, though head teachers report positive impacts, such as increased motivation and family involvement. The study also found that tablets are an integral part of students' lives, with many using them for social media and watching videos. The head of Honywood Community School supports tablet use, stating that it empowers students and reflects the modern world.

The "Growing Up in the City" exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool displays 25 photographs spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, depicting the evolution of childhood and social history in Liverpool. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibition showcases images of children at play, in costumes, and working, reflecting both the joys and hardships of growing up in the city. The collection, which will be on display until September 25th, was carefully selected from hundreds of images in the National Museums Liverpool's archives.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals, potentially playing against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, recommended to Gulls by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, is set to join subject to international clearance. Gulls manager Nicholson praises Keating's leadership and Anderson's stature, while noting the team's recent struggles with only one win in their last six games.

The new Bolivian law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental consent, aiming to address the country's poverty. It introduces stricter penalties for child violence, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. President Evo Morales supported the law, seeking a balance between local needs and international treaties. Over 500,000 children work in Bolivia, with some in harsh conditions. The law aims to reduce extreme poverty, despite international labor guidelines suggesting a minimum working age of 14. The ILO is reviewing the law for compliance with child labor regulations.

A 50-year-old woman, O'Donnell, experienced a "widow maker" heart attack after searching her symptoms online and self-medicating with aspirin. She had been helping a neighbor when she felt nauseous and feverish. The following day, she visited a cardiologist who found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. O'Donnell, a TV and film actress, had not called emergency services but urged others to recognize symptoms and call 911. Her talk show, The Rosie Show, was canceled due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old named Che Labastide-Wellington was fatally stabbed at a party in Kenton, London, after a scuffle in an alleyway. Initially, he was not involved in an altercation with a group of youths denied entry to the party. However, he was later targeted and stabbed around 00:30 GMT. He was pronounced dead an hour later. A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder, while two other boys, aged 15 and 16, were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December. A 14-year-old was arrested on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

A team of experts from Wales visited Aarhus, Denmark to learn from their new approach to cancer diagnosis, which was introduced in response to poor survival rates and long waiting times. The Danish model has three routes: fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with specific cancer symptoms, diagnosis centers for symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms that could potentially be cancer. The changes have led to better organization of patient diagnosis, improved survival rates, and Denmark is catching up with other European countries in cancer care. The Welsh team believes there could be lessons learned from the Danish model to improve cancer care in Wales.

The UK government's decision to disband the OFT leads to Powys winning a bid to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents or those breaching laws. Powys will receive £170,000 annually for this role and will work with local authorities, referring cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team, aiming to demonstrate Powys' capability for future contracts and external work.

The Nuffield Trust review, commissioned by NHS Employers, explored ways to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce to address staff shortages and adapt to the changing nature of care. The report found examples of nurses filling in for doctors and pharmacists for GPs, and suggested that expanding the skills of non-doctor staff could improve patient care and provide more rewarding roles. However, unions and medical associations warned against using this as a quick fix for staffing issues, emphasizing the importance of quality training for doctors and sufficient funding for training courses.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed by Avon and Somerset Police due to a crash at Rackfield Place, causing disruptions and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First services resumed partially, with a full service expected for the evening commute. The public and staff are thanked for their support and understanding.

The passage discusses a dispute between NRW and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) over the environmental impact of the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon project. NRW estimates that the lagoon would cause a 21% salmon and 25% sea trout annual death rate, while TLP argues these figures lack scientific basis and their own computer modelling estimates a worst-case scenario of 2% fish death rate. TLP also criticizes NRW for not sharing its methodology. NRW defends its approach, stating it has received a large amount of evidence and engaged in detailed discussions with TLP, and its findings have been independently assessed. The Welsh Government supports the project but seeks clarity on the UK government's stance.

The Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister of Stormont, Arlene Foster, announced the development of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland, similar to Scotland Food and Drink. The body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. Stormont's Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the move, stating that it could help coordinate marketing activities and drive export-led economic growth, but also noted potential implications for other organizations. The agri-food industry in Northern Ireland employs almost 100,000 people across various sectors.

The public is invited to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon as part of a Woodland Trust project commemorating WW1 victims. The four-year initiative aims to plant millions of native UK trees across four new woods in the UK, with 40,000 trees dedicated to the 40,000 Irish casualties. The project encourages local participation and hands-on contribution to create a wildlife habitat and space for reflection. The trees will stand as a tribute to those affected by the war.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," which tackles domestic violence and honor crime. The novel is a thriller featuring Detective Inspector Marnie Rome. The award was given at the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival, where Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career writing about detective VI Warshawski. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime, an organization supporting female crime writers.

The passage discusses the return of player Mitch Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, to Worcestershire county cricket team after recovering from a finger injury he sustained in 2016. Steve Rhodes, the director of cricket, expressed that Santner's absence last summer was a significant setback for the team's qualification hopes. Santner, who debuted in Test cricket in 2015, will rejoin the team after the ICC Trophy in June. He had a positive experience with Worcestershire and is eager to contribute to the team's success. Additionally, the team signed Australia's John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in a hit-and-run accident in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, is suspected of orchestrating the murder to inherit his assets. The coroner ruled the killing as unlawful, and a close friend testified to having no doubt about Barry's murder. Despite the Ukrainian police closing the case initially, it was reopened as a murder inquiry in 2011, but is not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, a 3-year-old from Merseyside, needs to return to Seattle for experimental T-Cell Therapy treatment unavailable in the UK, after his last transplant failed. His family is grateful for an anonymous donor who paid for the treatment, which will start as soon as possible. Charlie has been ill since age three, and after a third relapse in April, there were no more treatment options available in the UK. The family received confirmation of the donation via email from the hospital.

The passage discusses the implementation of a two-step verification system by Apple to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud accounts and protect intimate photos of celebrities from being stolen. The system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent via text or the Find My iPhone app after typing their username and password on a new device. Although the feature was available before, it wasn't activated when using Apple's backup service. The new security measure has been praised by experts, who suggest making it the default option for all users. However, concerns remain about the difficulty of remembering the recovery key and the possibility of it being stolen. Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

A deal is being discussed for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay, a club in the Isthmian League Premier Division, and become a club director. The club currently stands eighth in the division, three points away from a play-off spot. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant and non-league football player, is involved in the deal with multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who recently took over the club and has been investing £10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

The passage discusses a situation where Mr. Ashley is asked to provide evidence about his workers' treatment at a Derbyshire company's warehouse, following a BBC investigation. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright has given Mr. Ashley until 21 March to respond. Mr. Ashley had invited the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Mr. Wright, to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook. The committee is set to review the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage. Mr. Ashley has not yet accepted any alternative dates offered by the committee for the meeting. If he fails to agree to attend, the committee may seek the House of Commons' support for a contempt complaint. Sports Direct, owned by Mr. Ashley, has not commented on the BBC's request for a statement.

The report, titled Putin. War, was initiated by murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov's colleagues to accuse President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. The report is based on facts from Russian and foreign media, highlighting the human and economic cost of the conflict. It argues that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial in pro-Russian rebels' victories in eastern Ukraine, with volunteer soldiers admitting they were directed by Russian generals. The report also details Russian spending on the conflict and the lack of compensation for dead soldiers' families. Despite the opposition seeking donations to extend the initial print run, publishing and distributing such material is challenging due to fear among publishers and the question of public interest. The report accuses Putin of masterminding the war to boost his popularity, a claim that has not yet led to significant protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was discovered dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire due to head injuries. The 34-year-old from Rotherham had a post-mortem examination. Following his death, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the tensions between the UK and Welsh governments regarding the drafting of the Article 50 letter and the return of powers after Brexit. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed frustration that he and the devolved administrations were not consulted in the drafting process, despite the UK government's aim to develop a negotiating framework for the entire UK. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns responded by highlighting the UK government's efforts to consider the interests of Wales. The passage also raises questions about which powers will be devolved to Wales and whether funding will accompany these powers after 2020. The UK government's intentions regarding the devolution of powers remain unclear.

In Newry, two cars were damaged during an incident on Nursery Drive and Parkhead on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the "mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community". The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were attacked while performing their duties and urged parents to monitor their children's activities.

Mr. Charney, founder and former CEO of a company, was removed due to employee complaints, accusations of fund misuse, and a lawsuit against the company for defamation. The board stated they do not expect him to return, citing his violation of company policies, including sexual harassment and discrimination. Evidence of inappropriate emails and racially derogatory comments were presented in court. A restraining order was also issued against Mr. Charney to prevent negative press statements and attempts to remove board members.

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between GB and Greece, which will be covered on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The game is significant as it is GB's only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017. Three members of the Greek team will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. The game will take place at the Copper Box in London, and it is seen as an opportunity for GB to prepare for EuroBasket. The game will be broadcast from 17:30-19:30 BST on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website.

The passage recounts the author's experience with the first iPhone launch in 2007, initially dismissed but later recognized as a transformative moment in technology. The iPhone revolutionized the way people use their phones, integrating cameras, internet access, and email into a single device with an attractive user interface. The author reflects on the impact of the iPhone on photography and other activities, acknowledging the initial skepticism but ultimately appreciating the historical significance of the event. The passage also mentions the ongoing innovation in technology by companies like Amazon and Google.

The passage reports multiple cat poisonings in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, with all cats near Victor Avenue found to have ingested a toxic substance, possibly antifreeze. Seven-month-old Meereen died recently, following three other cat deaths in the past week and another two weeks prior. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and has urged locals to store chemicals safely, especially during the time of year when antifreeze is commonly used in cars. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, described the cat's distress and subsequent death after it exhibited symptoms of poisoning.

The passage discusses the current situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is about to implement more austerity and liberalization measures despite previously opposing them. The country's tourism industry is booming, but Greeks are not protesting against the upcoming economic hardships. This is attributed to the realization that there is no alternative (TINA) after the near-death experience in July. Despite failing to end fiscal austerity, Tsipras remains popular, but the new bailout deal will only work if it offers hope for better times. Creditors are urged to ease Greece's debt burden to enable genuine recovery.

Ross Kemp, who portrayed Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and 2005-2006, will make a brief return for Barbara Mitchell's final episodes. Dame Barbara, played by Jean Slater, will be killed off after revealing her cancer has returned. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character in the soap's 30-year history, will reunite with his brother Phil and their mother for the last time. The episode will showcase the Mitchell brothers facing the loss of their mother and reconnecting with old loves.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recognized the moment they were informed of her death that it was Harry. Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice and had stalked her. Despite warnings from Alice's mother, who had tried to reassure her daughter that the police were aware of the situation, the tragedy occurred. The Ruggles family has since established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. Dhillon was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The French firm EDF, financing most of the £18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, approved the funding, but the UK government will review the project further before backing it. Critics have raised concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign government involvement, as one-third of the cost is provided by Chinese investors. The project has faced delays and uncertainties, and EDF has had to raise money from its owners to fund it. Greenpeace has called for more investment in renewable energy.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the applicant's spouse committed adultery with. Family lawyers argue that this can add conflict and complexity, although there is no obligation to name anyone. The form's guidance states it is not normally necessary to name the third party. However, if named, the third party becomes part of the court case, receiving paperwork and a chance to respond, which could delay proceedings and incur additional costs. Adultery was cited as the reason for 12,148 divorces in England and Wales in 2015. The Ministry of Justice clarified that while it's possible to name the third party, there is no obligation to do so.

The passage discusses the tension between environmental and commercial forestry interests in Wales. Ministers are accused of prioritizing the environment over timber production, with Britain being a major wood importer. Confor, representing forestry businesses, highlights the loss of 40,000 acres of commercial forest since 2001 and the need for replanting. The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social factors in forestry, promoting native species and public access while supporting the industry through initiatives like Glastir. However, bureaucratic hurdles and a focus on environmental goals are seen as hindering commercial forestry growth, despite a significant market demand for timber.

A boy was severely injured in Coatbridge after being hit, leading to emergency services being called to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at around 16:40. He was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where he is in a serious condition.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoys veterans, including 91-year-old Charles Lewis, despite initial opposition from the Foreign Office due to rules on foreign medals. The Arctic Convoys, which consisted of vessels travelling from Britain to northern Russia during WWII, faced threats from German U-boats, aircraft, and harsh weather conditions. The Russian Embassy stated that the ceremony was important to recognise the veterans' contribution to the war effort and the alliance between Britain and Russia. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in defending Russia or its interests.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation discovered delays and a high rate of offenders not completing their mandated unpaid work, with some completing only 16 hours over 17 months. The Ministry of Justice is implementing recommendations from a report that identified issues such as poor organization and the need for more effective rehabilitation. The report also praised high-quality work and positive offender experiences. The chief inspector of probation called for urgent action to improve the system.

The passage discusses the criticism faced by a wealthy comedian, who is accused of hypocrisy for advocating for economic and political change to help the poor while living in a luxury home. The comedian, known for his vlogs The Trews, has been confronted about his living situation and responded defensively. He acknowledges the hypocrisy charge but argues that systemic change is necessary to address wealth inequality. He also reflects on his past actions and the role of fame and fortune in his life. The comedian has been criticized for hypocrisy before and continues to address these accusations through social media.

The passage describes the career of biologist and entrepreneur Dr. Craig Venter, who played a pivotal role in mapping the human genome and creating synthetic life forms. Initially criticized by the scientific community for his competitive approach, Venter's work accelerated genomic research. His background includes a transformation from a surfer to a determined medical researcher inspired by his experiences in Vietnam. Venter's innovations in gene sequencing, particularly focusing on RNA, led to rapid advancements in the field. Despite controversy over his methods and the commercialization of genomic research through Celera Genomics, Venter's contributions have been significant, culminating in the creation of Synthia, the first synthetic organism, and his ongoing work in marine genomics. His efforts have potential implications for environmental sustainability and industrial innovation.

A survey of 1,000 parents in England found that 80% of children who ate school lunches tried new foods, with carrots, sweetcorn, and peas being the most popular vegetables. The School Food Trust commissioned the research after a Mumsnet survey suggested parents packed lunches due to perceived fussiness. School meals are now subject to strict nutritional guidelines, and more children in Scotland eat school lunches (46%) compared to England (40%).

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish player at Euro 2016, transferred to Juventus in 2014 from Real with a buy-back option for Real worth up to 30m euros. He scored three goals for Spain in the tournament and netted 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia trophies. Morata participated in consecutive Champions League finals, scoring in the 2015 loss to Barcelona. He began his career at Real, debuting at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the team.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, returned to Championship team Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He made 51 appearances during his second stint at the City Ground, after spending four years at the club and later joining Celtic. Wilson has also played for Preston North End and Notts County. He is currently without a team after being released in May.

The third-largest global retailer, Tesco, is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to a private equity company, Yucaipa. As part of the deal, 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business £80m, and the remaining 50 stores will be closed. The sale will cost Tesco £150m, but they may recover some of this if Yucaipa turns the business profitable and Tesco buys a stake. Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits in 20 years.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but overcame it, considering representing France before aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics in martial arts. It also mentions a guide on getting into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields in the French Alps covered 375 sq km, which decreased to 275 sq km by the late 2000s. The retreat of glaciers is more significant in the southern sectors, with the Belledonne Massif losing almost all its glaciers and the Ecrins Massif experiencing a retreat rate more than three times stronger than the Mont Blanc Massif. The northern Alps have seen less retreat due to higher elevation, more precipitation, and cloud cover. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has decreased from 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to just over 30 sq km today.

The Scots, having won all five qualifiers, are set to host Iceland in a crucial match that could secure their place in the finals. Despite their strong performance, the team has experienced play-off losses in previous attempts to qualify for major tournaments. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, is also undefeated. The match and the return fixture will determine the group winner. Scotland's goalkeeper, Evans, and veteran player Gemma Fay have long aimed to reach the finals. With the best six runners-up qualifying automatically, Scotland is in a good position to reach the finals without a play-off. Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, believes that having players in top leagues benefits the national team.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England on allegations of online harassment made by a woman from south London, claiming harassment over two years through tweets. Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was released on bail and responded that the tweets were not threatening and criticized media coverage. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the case, with Campbell due in court in mid-September.

The People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) has suggested replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot in Skegness with a fish-themed, animal-friendly version, arguing that the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, has responded by saying that the Jolly Fisherman is loved by both adults and children and does not portray animal cruelty. He also stated that the current mascot would not be replaced unless the council felt it was necessary.

The passage describes a rugby match where Scotland dominated against Georgia, leading to a final score of 38-16. Scotland scored six tries, with significant contributions from Tommy Seymour, Stuart Hogg, and Hamish Watson. Vasil Lobzhanidze scored two tries for Georgia, but Scotland's strong performance, including a high possession rate of 91%, and effective counter-attacks led to their victory. Scotland's coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's pragmatic approach and improvement in game management.

Widnes led 14-6 at half-time and extended their lead to 38-12 in a rugby match against Castleford. Despite Castleford scoring three tries in four minutes, Widnes maintained their lead, with a final score of 44-26. Widnes moved up to seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth place. The victory marked Castleford's fourth consecutive home league defeat. Key players for Widnes included Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, while Paddy Flynn scored for both teams.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old man held at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 on suspicion of al-Qaeda and Taliban links, was released after a US review panel found him not to be a continuing significant threat. He had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. Following his release, he will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait, as per the release terms. His release was advocated by the Kuwaiti government, and he is the first inmate freed since May. The total number of inmates at Guantanamo is now 148.

Thousands attended an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph to commemorate Anzac Day, marking the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, with the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia sung at the end. The first Anzac Day commemoration in the capital was in 1916, and since then, services have become an important moment for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians. The Australian high commissioner to the UK addressed the crowds, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings and the courage of the Anzac troops. The ceremony featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, has joined Premiership Well for a second time and is set to make his debut for St Mirren against Alloa. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has been training to maintain his fitness. Clarkson has two caps for Scotland and nearly 400 senior club appearances, having played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren currently stands eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of Alloa. Clarkson is eager to contribute to the team's success and climb the table.

The turkey company Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan, with assurances that existing pension schemes for workers would be honored. The final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and members have an alternative scheme. Boparan plans to restore the business to profitability through investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity for processing chicken and turkeys.

The council scrutinized issues with a new vessel, with Cowes crossing being free until 2 July to gather feedback. The project faced a "frustrating and disappointing start," with multiple breakdowns, groundings, and training issues leading to suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Local businesses, like Valu-4-U, suffered significant trade losses. The council ordered a project review and discussed potential compensation for affected parties. The transport councillor mentioned the vessel as a prototype with expected teething problems, which have been largely addressed, including electrical issues and vehicle damage on ramps. Grounding issues were also resolved through improved seamanship.

The House of Lords European Union Committee report highlights the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. The industry, which represents a small portion of the UK's GDP and employs a limited number of people, should not be marginalized in negotiations. Key issues include the potential need to allow EU-registered boats access to UK waters in exchange for market access, the complexities of shared fish stocks, and the possibility of different fisheries management regimes in the UK's constituent countries. The report suggests retaining elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy, such as science-based quotas. Despite challenges, there is optimism in the industry about gaining control over UK waters and the potential for a more sustainable and equitable fishing industry. The UK government has expressed a desire to maximize freedom for British companies in the single market while also reviewing fisheries management post-Brexit.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, admitted to possessing inappropriate images of young boys over a ten-year period. He was placed on the sex offenders register and given a community payback order. Following a GTC Scotland hearing, Geaney was removed from the teaching register due to his actions being fundamentally incompatible with the teaching profession. The panel concluded that there was a high likelihood of reoffending due to the duration and volume of the conduct, and Geaney was prohibited from reapplying to the register for two years.

Firefighters responded to a fire at a Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited site on Duncan Street on 2 March, causing train service disruptions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste due to concerns raised by the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) about fire safety and potential impact on residents, transport, and the environment. The company, managed by Asset and Land Group, has until 7 August to appeal the decision. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, and if unsuccessful in their appeal, the company must cease operations and remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire is still undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad of Syria has stated that Syria is making its best efforts to comply with the schedule to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline and facing attacks on weapon shipments. He criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, claiming Syria is defending against terrorist attacks and accusing the US of supporting terrorists. The Syrian government denied rebels' claims of seizing Aleppo's central prison. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 4% having left the country. The US and Russia have urged Syria to meet its obligations, with Russia setting a deadline of March 1 for the transfer of chemical weapons to the coast for removal. The OPCW has admitted the destruction process has been slowed due to security concerns.

England won the cricket match at Old Trafford against Pakistan, leveling the series with a significant margin. Joe Root, promoted to number three, delivered an exceptional performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, earning him the man of the match title. Pakistan struggled with their batting, with Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq being the only players to score over 50 in the first two Tests. England's coach, Trevor Bayliss, praised Root's performance, and former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott predicted a tight series, despite England's strong performance.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their families, and care providers to share their experiences to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will examine factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but criticizes the lack of provider representation on the advisory panel.

Sheerin, a former Dons midfielder and current player-manager at Red Lichties, has been chosen as the new manager of Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin, 39, was selected after a comprehensive process by Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser and had previously guided Arbroath to their first national trophy in 2011. He played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden before moving into coaching.

Swansea City has appointed Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams to lead the team in the upcoming match against Bournemouth after sacking Bob Bradley. The club is looking to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement, the former Derby manager, as the preferred choice. Swansea City, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, has experienced a decline since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis believes the team can stay up, but acknowledges the challenges they face. He emphasizes the importance of the club's history and the need to maintain the 'Swansea Way'.

The passage describes the career of biologist and entrepreneur Dr. Craig Venter, who played a pivotal role in mapping the human genome and creating the first synthetic life form, Synthia. Initially criticized by the scientific community for his competitive approach and perceived arrogance, Venter's work significantly accelerated genomic research. After serving as an orderly in Vietnam, he pursued a medical career with a focus on research. At the National Institutes of Health, he developed a method to rapidly sequence genes, leading to the first complete genome of a free-living organism. In 1998, he founded Celera Genomics to sequence the human genome, completing the task in 2001 alongside the public project. Despite controversy over data sharing, Venter's success allowed him to fund his own research institute and later create Synthia. His additional project, the Sorcerer II expedition, aimed to sequence marine microbial genomes to understand gene and protein functions. Venter believes synthetic microbes could revolutionize industry and help address environmental issues.

The Sutton Trust report highlights the low quality and short duration of many European apprenticeships, particularly in England, compared to countries like Germany. It suggests creating more apprenticeships to improve the economy and job prospects for young people. Currently, only 20% of English employers offer apprenticeships, with a small fraction being at the advanced level equivalent to A-levels. The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with a focus on quality and relevance to employers. The Department for Education acknowledges the need for reform and has already taken steps to improve apprenticeship standards. The Association of Colleges agrees with the need for more apprenticeships but raises concerns about the feasibility of creating 300,000 new places.

The Briton, Storey, secured a win over Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland, and is aiming for her 17th title in the upcoming road race. Storey, at 37, is Britain's most successful female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 golds, across cycling and swimming in six Paralympics. She began her career in swimming, winning six medals in 1992, before transitioning to cycling in 2005. Storey has won four golds at the 2012 London Games and 21 world titles in both sports. She is targeting further Paralympic success at the Rio de Janeiro Games next year.

Hereford United faced expulsion from the Conference Premier due to financial issues, despite a last-minute escape from relegation. Chester City replaced them in the Conference Premier after Hereford failed to meet payment deadlines. The club's debt, including unpaid wages and taxes, amounted to £148,000, with an overall debt of £225,000. Hereford's financial struggles worsened after being relegated from the Football League in 2012, with falling attendance and insufficient fundraising efforts. An offer to buy the club for £1 and clear debts was made by the Hereford United Supporters' Trust, but it was not accepted. Ultimately, London businessman Tommy Agombar took over the club, but they still failed to meet the final payment deadline and were expelled.

The passage discusses a 30-year-old former Manchester City player who has earned 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes in Euro 2016. The player also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps since 2004. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. The player's decision to leave was described as "common sense" by Milner.

Renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), Christopher Hogwood, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a lengthy illness. Celebrated for his contributions to the early-music movement, Hogwood conducted leading orchestras globally and produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood was a respected academic, having studied at Cambridge University and Harvard University, and held positions as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. His legacy continues through the AAM, now led by music director Richard Egarr.

A boy from Northern Ireland with unnamed identity is unable to attend mainstream school due to coping issues. His family requested a special school placement, but all local special schools are at full capacity. The boy's mother expressed concerns about the system's failure to accommodate her son and other families with similar needs. The Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland, aiming to provide placements close to children's residences starting in 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has made a takeover bid for Newport Gwent Dragons, with a vote scheduled for 9 May. Newport County, who have a lease to use Rodney Parade stadium until 2023, expect their contract to be honored. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two, and losing their Football League status would be devastating for the fans and the city of Newport.

The passage recounts the experiences of a man who was kidnapped by rebels during Sierra Leone's civil war and later became involved in fighting the Ebola crisis. After escaping the war and being influenced by a preacher, he turned his life around and helped establish an Ebola treatment clinic. He now believes in investing in young people to build a better future. The Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone resulted in 11,314 deaths, with the majority occurring in Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea.

A pottery firm's art collection, consisting of 80,000 items, was set to be auctioned to pay off pension debt. A public fundraising campaign successfully reached its goal within a month, allowing the collection to remain on display at the Barlaston museum. The collection will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and then loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The Wedgwood Museum inherited the pension debt after the firm's collapse in 2009. The collection's preservation is important for Staffordshire and Britain's cultural development.

The passage discusses a potential deal where Wright may buy a 20% stake in Billericay, a club currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant and non-league football player, could become a club director. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has invested £10,000 a week and signed former England international Paul Konchesky. The specifics of Wright's deal are still being finalized.

In a football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, Nathan Delfouneso scored for Blackpool after 12 minutes, but Sam Slocombe saved a goal from Matthew Briggs. Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester from a corner. Blackpool missed a chance to take the lead when Tom Aldred headed wide from a corner. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The disused Fawley power station chimney, set to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, is the focal point of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside. The power station, which closed in 2013 after 40 years, will feature a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The 1971-commissioned, 198m-high chimney, once powering one million homes, will be preserved as part of the development, with building potentially starting in 2018.

The 23-year-old British cyclist, Latham, won a bronze medal in the men's omnium at the Hong Kong championships, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham caught up with the lead pack, overtaking Adrian Teklinski of Poland and Lucass Liss of Germany. The British men's team pursuit lost to Italy in the bronze medal race. Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman praised Latham's final sprint, while six-time Olympic gold medallist Sir Chris Hoy highlighted Latham's sensible riding and strong finish. The young British women's team pursuit team, including Olympic gold medallist Barker, finished fifth in the heats and did not qualify for the bronze medal race. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.

Ross Kemp, who portrayed Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and 2005-2006, will make a brief return for the show's character Dame Barbara's final episodes. Barbara, played by Jean Slater, will be killed off after revealing her cancer has returned. Kemp's return will bring the Mitchell brothers, Phil and Grant, together for the last time to say goodbye to their mother. Grant Mitchell is a notable character in the show's 30-year history, involved in various family dramas.

Sadio Mane scored twice within 138 seconds in a disappointing performance by Spurs at Anfield. Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire to win and inability to cope with pressure. Spurs have struggled on the road, winning only twice since September and losing to Chelsea and Manchester United. Danny Murphy noted Spurs' defensive inconsistency and lack of pace in away matches. Chelsea could extend their lead at the top of the Premier League if they beat Burnley.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, but managed to hold on to Rivers State. The APC made historic gains, but failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than previous years. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader after losing power following 16 years in control.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July, will offer an augmented reality app for visitors. The app provides online access to festival information, videos, and interviews with performers like The Waterboys and Imelda May. The app will be updated during the festival, allowing global interaction and access to the festival atmosphere anytime.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools said parents tried to undermine her authority. The Department for Education will work with Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures. Park View and Nansen Primary were criticised for failing to promote the spiritual, moral, social and cultural development of pupils. Park View and Oldknow trusts have been given a list of actions to complete before 4 July. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw said "a culture of fear and intimidation has taken grip" in Birmingham schools. Parents at the schools have criticised Ofsted's reports and accused inspectors of bias.

Vinnie died in 2012 due to a preventable build-up of fluid in his brain, following a routine eye test by optometrist Honey Rose. The prosecution argues that Rose's failure to detect swollen optic discs and refer Vinnie for further investigation was grossly negligent and "criminal". The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with another man, filming the encounters, and sending explicit content to the victim's family. He was placed on the sex offenders register and sentenced at the High Court in Edinburgh after initially denying the charges. The offenses took place between September 2013 and September 2014, with an additional incident of abusive behavior towards the woman's family on Christmas 2014. Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, was deemed a moderate risk for re-offending.

Ireland made 165-5 in a T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson scoring 56 and Gary Wilson and William Porterfield contributing valuable runs. However, Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad helped Afghanistan to win with 171-4. Ireland lost Paul Stirling early in the game and Boyd Rankin due to a back problem. The teams will meet again in a second T20 match on Friday.

The Spanish champions, Barcelona, maintained they hadn't committed any offense regarding Neymar's transfer. They paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m. The total cost to the club, including various fees and taxes, is £106.8m. Amidst allegations of misappropriation of funds, Barcelona's president resigned. A Spanish judge found sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona made a voluntary tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential discrepancies in tax obligations. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao, and two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are alleged to have confessed to the murders. UK detectives in Thailand to review the case are returning to compile a report and update the families. The suspects, charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, could face the death penalty if found guilty. Concerns have been raised by the UK Foreign Office about the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds, with DNA from the suspects matching samples taken from Witheridge.

The Scottish women's football team has won all five qualifiers and is set to host Iceland in a crucial match that could secure their place in the finals. The team has experienced play-off losses in the past and aims to avoid further heartbreak. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland, is also unbeaten. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically for the finals in the Netherlands, with the best six of the eight group runners-up qualifying. The team consists of players from various leagues, including England, Sweden, and the United States. The experience of playing in top leagues benefits the national team, as it brings new skills and a different culture of play.

The passage discusses Apple's response to the hacking of celebrity iCloud accounts, where intimate photos were stolen using third-party software. Apple plans to enhance its two-step verification system to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud, requiring users to enter a four-digit code sent via text or the Find My iPhone app after logging in from an unfamiliar device. However, this feature is optional, and experts suggest making it the default setting. The updated system will also notify users via email when a backup is being downloaded. Despite these improvements, concerns remain about the potential loss or theft of the 14-character recovery key needed to regain account access. Security experts recommend that two-factor authentication should be the default for all users, not just an optional feature. Apple aims to encourage users to adopt stronger security measures.

The passage details the campaign expenditures of various UK political parties during the 2014 European elections. UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Tories £2,980,815, the Lib Dems £1,580,575, and Labour £1,027,339. The figures represent spending from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's spending equated to 68p per vote, Labour 26p, the Conservatives 79p, and the Lib Dems £1.45. The Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote), and including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087. All parties, except Labour, spent more than in the 2009 European elections.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals, potentially playing against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, is set to join the Gulls, pending international clearance. Gulls' manager Nicholson praises Anderson's leadership and Keating's potential. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, with only one win in their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, despite having no significant underlying health issues. The horse had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. Many Clouds had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. The cause of death was a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, which is rare in horses. Questions have been raised about whether the horse's previous tendency to overheat was related to his death, but the report concludes that the haemorrhage was the cause.

The passage discusses the farewell speeches of several MSPs, including former first minister Alex Salmond, Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, and former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie, who are all stepping down ahead of the May 5 election. Salmond emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to take on more governance responsibilities. McNeil warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system, while Goldie humorously mentioned her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was emotional during these speeches.

Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Harry Potter star, in the 2017 live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. Dan Stevens from Downton Abbey will play the Beast, while Kevin Kline will portray Maurice, Belle's father. Audrey Hepburn's role as Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper turned teapot, will be played by the unnamed star, previously voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Luke Evans co-stars as the villain Gaston, with Josh Gad as Gaston's sidekick LeFou. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set to begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios and will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet with victims' relatives to discuss the outcomes of new inquests into the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, where 96 football fans died. Evidence files on 23 suspects, 15 related to the disaster's causes and 8 to police conduct, have been referred to the CPS for potential charges. The families, represented by the Hillsborough Family Support Group, have been invited to a private meeting in Warrington to be informed of the decisions. The process has been a long struggle for the families, who seek accountability.

Chelmsford Prison is experiencing numerous incidents of contraband being thrown over the wall, with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis being the most common items. The prison is working to prevent these incidents, but more measures are needed. The Justice Secretary has been asked to find ways to tackle this issue. A nearby resident has witnessed packages being thrown over the wall multiple times, and the prison is organizing a meeting to discuss the issue. The former inmate mentioned the use of drones, but there is no evidence of this at Chelmsford Prison. Smugglers face up to two years in jail.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was hit by Brian Wright's car while crossing the road outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston, resulting in serious head injuries. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light or Blackburn, who was wearing appropriate clothing. The jury heard that traffic in the other direction had stopped, but Wright's VW Golf did not. Wright, who expressed remorse for the incident, is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Wright's eyes. The trial continues.

The passage discusses Scottish middle-distance runner Muir, who won't participate in the Commonwealths due to her veterinary medicine exams in May. Despite her love for representing Scotland, she prioritizes her degree. Muir believes she has at least two more Olympics in her and targets the World Indoor Championships in March. She recently achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m race.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare, Ireland, disappeared in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. He was last seen talking to an unidentified man dressed in black on CCTV footage outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. A search has begun at a site in Chapelizod in Dublin, involving excavations and expected to take several weeks. Earlier this year, a team of detectives reviewed the case and enhanced the CCTV footage. The man seen with Deely has not been identified, and the police have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Del Potro won a 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 match against Wawrinka, after missing more than two years due to injuries. This victory marks his first Grand Slam since 2014. He will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios, ranked 15th, advanced to the third round after overcoming Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match. He will play Feliciano Lopez next. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also advanced with routine victories.

Tunisia was initially expelled from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against the Confederation of African Football (CAF), but later apologized and was reinstated. Morocco faced a ban on participation in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw, which was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). Morocco was initially punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, but the fine was reduced by CAS. Equatorial Guinea replaced Morocco as the 2015 host. Tunisia faced disqualification from the next Nations Cup for their complaints but managed to reconcile with CAF. Both countries are now preparing for the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

The passage discusses McLaren's decline from a dominant force in Formula 1 to its current struggles. Once a team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, McLaren now finds itself fighting for the fourth row on the grid. The decline began in 2013 due to poor chassis design, despite having a strong engine. Although the team has improved its car, issues with the Honda power-unit persist. McLaren's history features periods of success and decline, with the team currently hoping to reverse its fortunes under the leadership of Ron Dennis. Despite past achievements and having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Jenson Button, the team has not won a race since 2012. The passage concludes with Dennis's belief that McLaren will return to success, with Alonso joining the team in 2015 to pursue a third title.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, following a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar, with alcohol served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge noted O'Neill's poor record and imposed fines of £3,000 and £1,000 on O'Neill and Thomas, respectively.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry made eight three-pointers in the game, surpassing his previous record of 272 set two years ago. Klay Thompson also contributed significantly with 26 points. The Warriors overcame a 13-point deficit, while the Trail Blazers' Lamarcus Aldridge scored 27 points and Damian Lillard added 20. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol scoring 16 points and 15 rebounds for the Bulls.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen visited Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at Melwood, under the impression that he was a competition winner. However, it soon became clear that van Velzen was a skilled free-kick specialist, impressing the Liverpool players with his abilities. Van Velzen, who has gained popularity on YouTube for his free-kick videos, described the experience as amazing and fulfilling, especially meeting his idol, Balotelli. He also shared a fun moment with the Liverpool forward by unveiling his infamous slogan.

he passage discusses the benefits of oophorectomy (ovary removal) for women with the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, who have been diagnosed with breast cancer. A study found that this procedure can reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60% for BRCA1 carriers. Women with the BRCA1 mutation have a 50-80% lifetime risk of developing breast cancer, and the procedure is particularly effective for those with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. The study also found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The procedure is recommended to be part of the treatment discussion for BRCA1 carriers with early-stage breast cancers.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were killed in North Carolina when they were hit by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday while on the tracks. The incident occurred in Durham, shortly before 10 am, involving train number 80, the Carolinian, traveling from Charlotte to New York City. The property where the accident happened was owned by Norfolk-Southern. Despite the tragedy, none of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, though one passenger did fall ill during the delay and received medical attention. The train was delayed for nearly three hours before it could continue its journey. The couple, who may have been living in a homeless camp according to a scrap metal collector who knew them, were pronounced dead at the scene. The train's next stop after the incident was Raleigh, about 25 miles away, and the usual travel time from Charlotte to New York City is approximately 13 hours and 30 minutes.

arlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an undercover DEA informant for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. Toro helped carry out undercover stings worldwide and aided in the prosecution of drug lord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, Toro was not paid for his work and was not granted citizenship. Now retired due to declining health, Toro faces deportation and lives in the US illegally. He has received financial support from a former colleague for an operation, as the DEA declined to assist him. Toro is currently in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits without a green card or passport.

The US regulator is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for its use of the '.sucks' domain name to charge celebrities and companies high fees to protect their reputations. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have been targeted. Vox Populi initially charged $2,499 a year for the domain name, but later offered it to consumers for $10 a year. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is considering taking action if the company's actions are found to be illegal.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found in a pond, wrapped in a Sainsbury's bag. The case was reopened when the body was exhumed for a review, and DNA samples led to the mother. She was initially suspected of infanticide but was not charged after explaining that the baby was stillborn and she had hidden her pregnancy. The case has now been closed, with no evidence of foul play. The baby has been reburied with a new headstone, and the mother remains on bail while the CPS decides on further charges.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of Young's moving car. The incident occurred when Young, mistakenly believing Hicks was trying to leave without paying, drove him back to the taxi rank at high speed. Hicks, who was 23 at the time, later developed epilepsy and requires constant care. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, and he was ordered to pay damages, with the exact amount to be determined in a further hearing. The judge reduced the damages by 50% due to Hicks' decision to jump from the moving vehicle.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night due to several storms, with a tornado reported 6 miles northwest of Goddard, posing risks to nearby communities. Nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. Tornado sightings were also reported in southwestern Kansas and Missouri. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

uke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight clash in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. Rockhold believes he needs to be aggressive and dominate Machida, who is known for his elusive style. Rockhold has analyzed Machida's weaknesses and is confident in his own diverse skill set. Machida, on the other hand, is focused on applying his technique and strategy to win the fight and earn a title shot. Both fighters have had recent victories and are well-prepared for the upcoming bout.

A light general aviation aircraft landed without deploying its landing gear at the Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, managed to re-engage the engines and take off again, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale with his dog, Buddy, where he landed safely. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error or mechanical fault. The FAA is investigating the incident.

anchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but has pledged to support him until the end of the season. Despite criticism of Toure's performances, Pellegrini believes the Ivorian does not need a break. City is reportedly open to offers for Toure in the summer as they look to rejuvenate their squad. Meanwhile, City's goalkeeper Joe Hart insists the players should take responsibility for their performances, not just the manager. In other news, West Ham's Aaron Cresswell has been warned by Sam Allardyce not to make the same mistake as other English players who moved to City.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the 'Godfather of Uxbridge,' was set to be extradited to Italy after being sentenced to seven years in 1999 for his involvement with the Cosa Nostra. However, his sentence was dropped as it expired last October, and his European arrest warrant will be withdrawn.
