Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, will now be allowed to remain in the UK with his family. The case will still need to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore was arrested in 2013 but was never convicted of murder. He had been living under the name Marc Skinner for two decades before his arrest.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of the three 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner line-up for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. He will be ridden by AP McCoy, marking his last ride in a Grade One race. McCoy's final day as a professional jockey will be finalized on Friday. The other runners include Special Tiara, Sacre, and Somersby. McCoy had previously announced his retirement after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February.

The mother of Marcia, a girl murdered 40 years ago, has seen crime scene photos of her daughter's body and now seeks revenge. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, and her body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Her mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, initially chose not to view the photos or the crime scene but later regretted the decision. She viewed the photos last year and was shocked by the condition of her daughter's body. Marcia's murder remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 after his DNA matched that found on the victim's clothing. He was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

ory McIlroy believes it's essential to win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, considering his past final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011 as a significant learning experience. As the sixth player aiming for all four major titles, he acknowledges the importance of winning at Augusta and views it as a special achievement. Despite only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy is optimistic about his chances, especially after his recovery and subsequent major wins following the 2011 incident. He plans to use the golf course as a sanctuary from the surrounding hype and pressure.

The passage highlights several trending stories from a busy week. These include four rainbows appearing in New York after heavy rain, captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming popular, but is now under scrutiny due to a crackdown on vice. RDJ showed agitation during a UK interview about his private life. A new trend called the #kyliejennerchallenge involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar. Alice Barker, at 102, revisited the past with filmmakers. A prom-posal referencing bombs sparked accusations of racism from the prom-poser. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', and Johnny Depp appears almost unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer. Lastly, a military dad photobombed his son in a creative announcement of pregnancy.

In the past year, 272 children in England were hospitalized due to fetal alcohol syndrome, a condition caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. However, experts suggest the actual number could be much higher, with the World Health Organization estimating that at least 7,500 babies born in the UK annually may be affected. The condition results in lifelong disabilities, as exemplified by 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who was diagnosed with fetal alcohol syndrome at age five. Other health issues linked to alcohol consumption during pregnancy include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Current government guidelines advise pregnant women to limit alcohol intake to two units no more than twice a week, but some experts recommend complete abstinence.

An ex-juvenile offender, Shaun Andrew Mckerry, known as 'Boomerang Boy', attempted to rob a post office in Shildon, County Durham, with an axe. He was thwarted by the shop owner, Sab Dhillon, who tackled him, and his wife, Sam, who hit him with a baseball bat, disarming him. The police arrived shortly after and arrested Mckerry, who was later sentenced to six years in prison for attempted robbery. Mckerry had a history of criminal behavior, earning his nickname due to his frequent returns home after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors in Canada are charged with gang rape and must stay in Nova Scotia for trial. They were given bail conditions requiring them to live on a Canadian naval base, surrender their passports, and continue working for the Royal Navy. The alleged assault occurred after a hockey game, and the sailors face up to 14 years in prison if convicted. The Royal Navy is responsible for employing them while the case proceeds through the court system.

mother of a four-year-old boy with a rare disease called Netherton's syndrome, which makes his skin appear scalded, was reported to the police by a stranger who mistook his condition for child abuse. The mother, Valerie Jackson, regularly applies creams to her son RJ's skin to alleviate the symptoms. The family often faces ignorance and cruel comments from others due to the boy's appearance. Netherton's syndrome is a rare congenital skin disease that affects one in 200,000 births in the UK, and there is no cure for it.

he controversial Protein World advertisements featuring model Renee Somerfield have been removed from the London Underground after sparking a backlash from feminists and body image campaigners. The ads, which promoted the slogan "Are you beach body ready?", were criticized for promoting an unhealthy body image and received over 200 complaints. The Advertising Standards Authority is assessing the complaints to determine if further action is needed. The posters were taken down as their three-week advertising period ended, but Transport for London (TfL) stated they would consider public reaction for future similar advertisements. Protein World has defended the ads, claiming they aim to inspire people to be healthier and fitter. The company has also faced threats and vandalism in response to the campaign. Despite the controversy, sales of protein powder in the UK continue to rise.

Rail firms are facing criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87% after the general election, despite promises from party leaders to freeze or cap prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has intervened, asking First Great Western to urgently review its decision to almost double fares on the London to Cotswolds route. The fare increase is set to affect off-peak returns, with passengers facing an 87% hike from £33.30 to £62.40. First Great Western claims the increase is to align the route with other services, but is offering some cheaper advanced single tickets. Other rail firms, like Virgin, have also implemented significant fare hikes, with Virgin stating that the majority of its increases affected cheaper, Virgin-only fares. The rail industry argues that fare increases are necessary to maintain services and infrastructure.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier and newlywed pensioner, was blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown by vandals targeting his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The incident occurred when he confronted the attackers after they began throwing stones at his property. Despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight. The couple, who recently got married, are now considering moving due to safety concerns. Police are investigating the attack, which appears to have no motive.

om Poynton, the Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension after a successful return from injury. The 25-year-old missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident. He made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Poynton will be available for the start of the season and has committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and work ethic following the tragic events of last April.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, lung, bones, and neck, has been declared cancer-free after a year of treatment. During his treatment, Harley wore a superhero mask, inspired by the Ninja Turtles, to help him feel stronger during radiotherapy. His story gained worldwide attention, and he was awarded a Little Star Award by Cancer Research UK. Harley underwent 80 days of chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy. He will continue to have regular check-ups to ensure he remains cancer-free.

Tim Sherwood believes Jack Grealish should focus on his club career at Aston Villa before deciding on his international future. The 19-year-old is in demand by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood emphasizes the importance of Grealish continuing to perform well for Villa to make an informed decision. Grealish's father also advises him to concentrate on his club football first. Grealish is expected to choose between the two countries at the end of the season.

The passage discusses the high landing fees for private jets at various airports, which can be a significant expense for wealthy travelers. Some of the most expensive airports for private jet landings are in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive. Other notable airports with high landing fees include Narita International Airport and Kansai International Airport in Japan, Toronto Pearson International Airport in Canada, and Dublin Airport in Ireland. Salzburg Airport in Austria and Laguardia Airport in New York also make the list. The passage also mentions that the busiest times for private jet travel are during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix.

The passage describes a video of Cooper, a Labrador, quickly eating an ice cream cone from McDonald's drive-thru with his friend Daisy. Owner Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, ensures Daisy gets her fill before Cooper due to his fast eating habits. The video has been viewed over seven million times, with mixed reactions from viewers. Gallegos defends feeding her dogs ice cream, citing her previous dog's long life and similar treat habits. Another video shows the dogs enjoying a Starbucks 'pup-uccino,' a whipped cream cup.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock, after initially joining as interim manager. He had signed a three-year deal with the club. Prior to this, he served as assistant manager to Allan Johnston. Locke took over the managerial role in February when Johnston left. Since then, he has maintained a strong performance, losing only once in seven games. He is set to discuss this at a press conference.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has been threatened with her autistic son Logan's suspension from Seminole County Elementary due to the use of essential oils from Doterra. The teachers claim the oils' scent is distracting to other students. Kemp uses the oils to help Logan stay calm and focused. Despite a letter from the school board citing the oils as a 'problem', Kemp plans to continue using them, arguing their natural benefits. The Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, referring to it as a 'health issue'. The oils used by the family include lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was destroyed by a massive fire that spread through 90 condos before the building collapsed. The fire, which started on a Wednesday afternoon, was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames but were unable to get inside the summer homes. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, with claims that it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper Complex is typically used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.

The Queen, at almost 89, was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park without a helmet, as is her custom. She has a lifelong love for horses, having first ridden at age four. Despite a knee injury reducing her riding time, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian and breeds Fell ponies and Highland ponies at her Hampton Court stud. The Fell pony, a breed dating back to the Neolithic period, is known for its docile nature and was used by various cultures throughout history. The Queen's interest in these ponies continues today.

A dispute over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbors escalated, resulting in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman. He was allegedly killed by a single punch to the head from 28-year-old Phillip Pama during an argument in front of their homes. Pama, a shift worker and father of three, was charged with manslaughter after being granted conditional bail. Yeaman, known for his loud music and behavior, was pronounced dead at the scene. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, in Russia attempted to hire a hitman to murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit. The police set up a sting operation, capturing Simonova's request on camera. She was arrested after handing over some money to the undercover officer posing as a hitman. Simonova now faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. Vanya, who ended the relationship for a classmate, expressed relief at Simonova's arrest.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea football manager, discusses his daily communication with God, which is separate from his professional life. He prays daily but does not discuss football with God or his wife. Mourinho, who has worked with the World Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger, tries to keep his personal and professional lives distinct. He attends church regularly only when in Portugal and prays for personal matters, not football-related issues. Despite his competitive professional life, Mourinho sees himself as a good person and family man. He also mentions making mistakes in his professional life due to the competitive and emotional nature of his job. Chelsea is currently leading the league. Mourinho's son celebrated a Chelsea victory recently. Mourinho and his family attended the Hunger Games premiere.

For the first time in eight years, Bob Barker, the original host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show, temporarily replacing Drew Carey. Barker, 91, successfully hosted the first price-guessing game before handing over the duties to Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker appeared to have no trouble with the hosting responsibilities.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin, who works with the foreign missions branch of the service, had his security clearance revoked and was put on leave following the arrest. This incident, along with another case of alleged misconduct by a high-ranking supervisor, has led to investigations by the Homeland Security Department's inspector general.

fearless freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, risked his life to capture a photo of a hungry lion in a safari park in Lahore, Pakistan. He managed to get within 10 feet of the lion, armed only with a camera, before the lion noticed him due to the camera's shutter sound. Atif had to quickly retreat to his car to avoid the lion's aggressive approach. Despite the danger, Atif expressed that he would not be able to repeat the experience.

The New York City Police have released an image of a tattoo found on an unidentified woman's body to help identify her. The woman, aged between 25 and 45, was found unconscious on a Brooklyn street on March 22 and was pronounced dead by paramedics. The distinctive tattoo, believed to be the name 'Monique' within a heart and a rose, is on her right leg. The cause of death is still unknown, and the police are awaiting a medical examiner's report. They are urging anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK and being unable to afford a property. The project took a year and a half to complete and cost about $25,000. The home, which features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and other comforts, is nearly self-sufficient, with most of its electricity coming from solar panels. The couple now live in the home, surrounded by nature, and plan to build another one in the future.

Researchers found that children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests compared to those who don't or have individual devices. The study, conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, involved 352 students and showed shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher. The collaborative learning around the technology was identified as the key factor, suggesting schools should reconsider tablet usage in early grades for maximum effectiveness. These findings will be presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

The passage describes a two-legged piglet from Qionglai city in Sichuan province, China, that has gained internet fame for learning to walk on its front trotters despite being born without back legs. The piglet, named 'Super Pig,' is able to balance and forage for food, endearing itself to viewers. It interacts well with its four-legged siblings and has attracted attention from villagers and tourists. The piglet's owner, Ms. Duan, noticed its uniqueness at birth. The story of the two-legged piglet mirrors that of a rabbit in Liuzhou zoo that also learned to walk on its front paws, becoming a star attraction.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips from Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana when he was hit by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone, who was on lap 25 for tires and fuel, spun while exiting his pit box and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg and was released. Dracone, who spun out on turn one, did not finish the race and placed 23rd. The race was affected by rain, causing traction issues for many cars.

The passage describes a horrific crime where Milton Vieira Severiano, a 32-year-old man, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, also known as Amanda Buno. The crime was captured on CCTV footage, showing Severiano smashing his wife's head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. He confessed to the crime, stating jealousy as the motive. The incident occurred in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, shortly after their wedding. Severiano was later arrested after crashing a stolen car, with police finding multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle. He now faces life imprisonment.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, known for her book "I Quit Sugar," has publicly discussed her personal struggle with mental illness, including a near-suicide experience due to anxiety. In an interview with Women's Weekly Australia, she described how a mix of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and a lack of family support led her to question the value of her life. Wilson, now 41, has found some peace with her condition and emphasizes the connection between depression and anxiety. She notes that anxiety is becoming more prevalent, with one in three Australian women expected to experience it in their lifetime. Wilson encourages those in need to seek help from organizations like Beyond Blue or Lifeline.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she beat her boyfriend's former girlfriend with a crowbar upon finding her using heroin in her bathroom. The incident occurred in November 2014, and Curtin was set to go to trial, but the charges were dropped as she was deemed justified in her actions under Oregon law, which allows the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney argued that the ex-girlfriend had been harassing and threatening Curtin. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a nearly six-year prison sentence.

The passage describes a video of Gemma, a pit bull from California, who is being tricked by her owner into eating broccoli by mixing it with her treats. Gemma reacts with disgust, spitting the vegetable out on the floor. The passage hopes that Gemma's negative reaction to broccoli won't influence the two children in her home to dislike vegetables as well. It also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized for a link on its official website that directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was intended for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was shut down in 2011. The porn site took over the address after the awards were scrapped and the organizers allowed its registration on HSBC's website to retire. HSBC removed the hyperlink and insisted its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 during a house fire in Clinton, providing firefighters with instructions to rescue him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah. Marcus stayed calm during the 11-minute call, comforting his sister and guiding the firefighters to their location. Prince George's County firefighters entered the room by breaking a window and rescued the siblings. The children were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while the other three family members escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Images have surfaced of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, New South Wales. The neon glow, captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson, is caused by millions of plankton emitting light, creating a 'beautiful supernatural scene'. A similar event occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explains that the glow is from noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn, and is usually harmless. The algae emits light as a defense mechanism against its prey, diatoms.

ew tests that identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors can help determine the aggressiveness of the disease and the risk of recurrence. This allows some patients to avoid chemotherapy, which can have severe side effects. The tests, such as Endopredict, are currently available privately and cost around £2,500. Experts believe these tests can help patients make informed decisions about their treatment, potentially saving costs for the NHS by avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy. One patient, Becca Cornford, was able to avoid chemotherapy after her test showed a low risk of recurrence.

ver 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with five from HMS Ocean alone in the past nine years. The evacuations, often referred to as'medevacs', also occurred on other ships like HMS Illustrious, HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond. The Ministry of Defence stated a strict 'no touching' rule at sea, implying pregnancies likely occurred before or during leave. The data was released following the return of Commander Sarah West, the first female Royal Navy warship captain, due to personal reasons. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, they made up 9% of the personnel. In the Army, 99 female soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan due to pregnancy between 2006 and 2013. Military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones, and they are usually flown back on flights meant for injured troops.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House. The drone had a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The incident raises concerns about potential terrorism involving drones, especially during events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was not in his office at the time of the discovery. There are currently no flight restrictions for drones in most of Tokyo.

security guard from China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-suffering mother to work with him on his motorbike every day. He ties a sash around their waists to prevent her from falling off during the four-kilometer journey. His wife works in a different city and his son is still in school. Lu feels it's his duty to care for his mother, who used to care for him and his siblings. He checks on her throughout the day to ensure she hasn't wandered off.

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking in the US increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, largely due to rising rates among women. The study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, also found that binge drinking rates rose by nearly 36% among women in Santa Clara County, California, compared to 23% among men. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. The researchers attribute the increase in binge drinking to changing social norms, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study also found that alcohol-related deaths in the US reached 88,600 in 2010, and the cost of excessive drinking was estimated at more than $220 billion per year.

The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. The procedure should only be done when medically necessary due to potential complications, including infections and death. The WHO suggests the ideal caesarean rate should be between 10% and 15%, as the current rate in England is over 25%. The WHO statement contradicts NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans for women with anxiety about childbirth or previous complicated births. The WHO emphasizes that doctors are underestimating the risks and carrying out caesareans too often.

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins, was arrested for breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for a week, and selling the owners' belongings at a yard sale. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The homeowner, Mark Conklin, found Filkins in his living room and called the police. Items missing include furniture, a grill, lamps, posters, pots, pans, linens, and a painting. The police are requesting the return of the stolen items and offering assistance to those who unknowingly purchased them. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was returned to her after Albury police station posted a series of humorous photos and selfies on her Facebook page. The phone was handed in to the police station on a Sunday morning, and officers used the unlocked phone to post content on Bella's page, including a photo of the phone in a holding cell and playful messages about the phone's battery life and status. Bella had lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the previous night and only realized it was missing the next day. When she arrived at the police station, her friends and the officers recognized her from the Facebook posts. Bella was able to reclaim her phone without having to provide identification, as the officers were already familiar with her from the social media interactions. Bella later added a password to her phone and expressed gratitude to the police for their creative and effective approach to returning her lost device.

A five-day-old baby hippo was tragically killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa. The calf's mother, attempting to protect her young, watched in horror as the baby was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface. Despite her efforts, the mother was unable to save her calf, which died from its injuries hours later. The incident was witnessed by a tour operator, Stacey Farrell, who speculated on the possible reasons for the attack, including play or jealousy.

three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of the most expensive areas in Britain, is on sale for £575,000, significantly lower than neighboring homes due to its remaining three-year lease. The property, in need of modernization, could be worth over £6 million if the lease is extended. The apartment, located in exclusive Egerton Place, has 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, a utility room, a lift, parking, and a communal garden. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson, the same price as a three-bedroom house in Stanmore, Middlesex. The freeholder is believed to be the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease for 90 years could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, leading to free drink giveaways. The issue, which began on Friday evening, was resolved without a clear explanation of the cause. The outage disrupted sales, as registers could not accept credit cards, but cash transactions were still possible. Starbucks issued an apology and promised to update once systems were back online. The incident occurred shortly after the company reported record quarterly earnings. Some stores closed early to prevent further giveaways, and the news of free drinks spread quickly on social media.

Terrorists are receiving training in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, to radicalize Muslims. Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit stated that these individuals blend in with the community but have hidden motives. Terrorism in Wales dates back to 1998, with several locations used for training, such as the Brecon Beacons and the National Whitewater Centre in Bala. The European Institute of Human Sciences in Llanybydder is also linked to terrorism, as one of the murderers of Fusilier Lee Rigby studied Arabic there. Community intelligence is crucial in combating terrorism.

A species of whale, previously thought to be extinct, the Omura's whale, was discovered washed up on a remote beach in Western Australia. This is the first sighting of the species in the region and only the second in Australia. The 5.68m juvenile female whale was initially hard to identify, but was confirmed as an Omura's whale through DNA profiling. The discovery is significant as very little is known about this species, which was only scientifically described in 2003 and is typically found in tropical and subtropical waters such as Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale's unique features include a sleek body shape and 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton for further study and possible public display in museums.

The passage discusses the controversial view that hormones should be a factor in considering presidential candidates, specifically targeting female candidates like Hillary Clinton. Cheryl Rios, a female CEO, argues that women's hormones make them unfit for leadership roles, such as the presidency. The text counters this argument by highlighting historical examples of male leaders whose decisions may have been influenced by hormones, and by citing studies that show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. It also points out the existence of gender bias in the workplace and the need for a serious discussion about ending it. The passage concludes by emphasizing the benefits of gender equality for the nation, economy, and families.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is selling his extensive antique collection in a £100,000 auction to downsize his home. The auction, organized by Dominic Winter Auctioneers, features over 200 items, including a 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow, paintings, furniture, swords, rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. Hardy, an 89-year-old military history enthusiast and medieval longbow expert, expressed sadness at parting with his collection, which he amassed due to his passion for classic literature and military history. The auction will also include rare books, some from the 17th century.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a Florida man wanted for the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky. He failed to show up for a supervised visit with his son on the day of his mother's murder. He has a history of bipolar mental illness, was previously on parole for battery on law enforcement, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for attempted suicide. Neighbors speculate that the stress of divorce proceedings may have triggered the murder. The murder weapon has not been publicly identified, and Shemansky was last seen fleeing the scene without provisions or medication. His estranged wife is preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home.

The city of Eugene, USA, has been granted the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council. This decision was made without the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack expressed enthusiasm for the decision, highlighting the collaboration between public authorities, private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the public. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

eonie Granger, an aspiring model, was jailed for 16 years for luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death in a plot to steal his winnings. Granger, 25, used her looks to befriend Hassan, 56, and convinced him to take her to his flat, where her boyfriend and an accomplice tied him up and beat him to death. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, while her co-defendants, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 36 years. The three defendants were also convicted of robbing Hassan and conspiring to falsely imprison him.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season, with poor performances in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland and a dip in form since Christmas. Despite this, he has still contributed to Chelsea's success in the Premier League and the Capital One Cup. Fabregas has a history of a late-season slump, and his current form has raised concerns about his durability. However, he has the potential to provide crucial assists in the remaining games, which could help Chelsea secure the Premier League title.

West Ham is in talks to sign Jamaican player Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United, who has impressed during his trial with the club. Beckford, considered one of the hottest Caribbean prospects, also has offers from Belgian clubs. West Ham is also offering affordable season tickets at the Olympic Stadium for the 2016-17 season.

he police have abandoned an investigation into a brutal attack on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman, despite substantial evidence against a suspected attacker. The assault, carried out by balaclava-clad protesters wielding iron bars on ropes, occurred three months ago. Lane, who was beaten while leading the Tedworth Hunt, suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. A video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of some saboteurs, were provided to the police. However, the police have halted the investigation due to insufficient evidence and have not identified, charged, or prosecuted anyone involved. This decision has sparked outrage among hunt supporters and calls for a ban on face coverings for saboteurs.

Adam Gadahn, known as Azzam the American, was a prominent American member of al-Qaeda who acted as the organization's chief English-language propagandist. Born in 1978, he converted to Islam in 1995 and left the US for Pakistan in 1998. Gadahn was indicted for treason and material support to al-Qaeda in 2006. He appeared in numerous al-Qaeda videos, urging attacks on American and Western interests and criticizing US Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama. Gadahn was killed in a US counterterrorism operation in January, alongside Ahmed Farouq and hostages Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto.

he passage discusses the rising popularity of a five-year-old Chinese basketball prodigy, Mai Zizhuo, who has been showcasing impressive basketball skills since he was two and a half years old. A viral video of him playing basketball has garnered significant attention and praise from fans across China, with many comparing him to the country's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming. The video features Mai scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. The remarkable skills displayed by the young player have left many netizens in awe, with some questioning the authenticity of the video and others expressing a desire to improve their own basketball skills.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which advocated for the legalization of child sex in the 70s and 80s, has become a supporter of the media pressure group Hacked Off. The group campaigns for state involvement in media regulation and a statutory body to regulate the press. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament to lobby MPs for this cause. His association with the group is likely to cause controversy due to his past affiliations.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, transforming it into a catwalk for a ten-piece unisex clothing collection designed to be worn in 20 ways. The show, featuring models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall, was headlined by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, owners of the Icebergs restaurant. The event was held on a sunny day with a crowd of spectators, including beachgoers and passers-by, enjoying the show and the weather.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a day at a safari park in Northern California with his family, where he posed with a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Earlier, he announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was removed from an Israeli memorial wall after his family and the victims' organization Almagor objected to his inclusion. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, but Almagor argued that his death was a "rogue attack" and not an act of terrorism. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, agreed to remove Abu Khdeir's name following the complaints. His name has also been removed from the organization's website.

The passage describes a YouTube video by user Lionel Hutz, where his young son chases their cat around the garden to rest on its belly. The cat licks its fur before the boy sits on it, but the cat soon gets up and moves away. The boy follows the cat and repeats the action until the cat leaves. Later, a video shows the boy feeding the cat treats, indicating they've reconciled.

In a Philadelphia police corruption trial, former drug dealer witness Robert Kushner lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past marijuana sales. Kushner, one of over a dozen witnesses, claimed that undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him in 2007. The school stated they were unaware of Kushner's criminal history, as he had passed a background check when hired in 2010. Kushner's past charges were expunged, but he was arrested again in 2011 and pleaded guilty to DUI in 2008. The defense argues that the government's case relies on lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Fujian Province, China, injured six people and caused a large fire. The plant in Zhangzhou City produces paraxylene, a potentially carcinogenic chemical. The blast happened after an oil leak at an oil storage facility. Over 600 firefighters controlled the fire. The plant had another explosion in 2013 with no casualties. Protests against such plants have occurred due to pollution concerns. The Zhangzhou plant was moved from Xiamen in 2007 due to public backlash.

ack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low and using children's shinpads due to superstition. Despite Premier League referees' comments, Grealish insists he will not change his ways. He made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing satisfaction at the opportunity, despite the team's loss. Grealish appreciates his manager's faith in him and hopes for more starts in the future.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. Despite recent claims by her father Bobby Brown that she is awake, medical professionals maintain that she has not shown any response to visitors or familiar voices. She has a tracheostomy in her throat and is undergoing rehabilitation, but the quality of her life in the future is still uncertain.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead against Germany, after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Russia needs one more win from the Sunday's three matches to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales (NSW) are being warned to prepare for more floods and storm damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. The upcoming storm, an east coast low, is expected to bring heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that the new storms will hinder clean-up efforts from the previous week's wild weather, with 4,000 out of 24,196 jobs still pending. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, which was severely affected by the last storm. Meteorologists are monitoring a trough of low pressure forming along the coast, which is expected to hit the far northern parts of the state the hardest. The Bureau of Meteorology has indicated that the main impacts of the upcoming storm will be on coastal areas in the northeast, including the northern rivers and mid north coasts, as well as southeast Queensland. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

odel Nina Moric, who appeared in Ricky Martin's music video for "La Vida Loco," has addressed claims that she attempted suicide. She clarified that she collapsed due to low blood pressure and was hospitalized, showing photos of her injuries on Instagram. Italian media reports suggested she tried to commit suicide and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment, with her boyfriend allegedly confirming the incident. However, Moric denied these reports, stating her boyfriend was in Naples at the time and that she only needed rest after the fall. She also mentioned a past incident in 2009 where Italian media claimed she took an overdose, but she refuted this as well. Moric was once married to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, who was imprisoned for blackmailing celebrities.

The British public hopes that Prince William and Kate Middleton's second child will have a traditional name, with Diana being the top choice for a girl, in honor of Prince William's late mother. Alice and Charlotte are also popular choices. If the child is a boy, James is the preferred name. The majority of people support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded 64, including an Afghan lawmaker, near a group of protesters in Khost city, eastern Afghanistan. The attack occurred while the protesters were heading to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other organization has claimed it. The incident happened around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The Brazilian right-back enjoyed seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. Negotiations have ended, with Alves' agent stating it's hard that Barcelona didn't think about renewing his contract earlier. The 31-year-old couldn't agree on a new deal and will depart the Nou Camp this summer.

Pablo Osvaldo has invited Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Argentine club Boca Juniors. He believes they would be a good fit for the team and their presence would be greatly appreciated by the fans at the La Bombonera stadium. Osvaldo praises their South American style and their abilities, stating that Pirlo and Totti would be perfect for Boca Juniors. Totti, in particular, is a Roma legend and Osvaldo feels he would be equally loved in Argentina.

he passage describes an incident where amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, 18, experienced a spectacular fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the dramatic nature of the fall, which has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online, Ferguson sustained only a cut on his nose. He returned to riding the next day and is determined to continue his career in racing. Ferguson's accident has led to some playful banter and an increase in his Twitter followers, and he humorously suggests that he might consider a career in gymnastics due to the somersaults involved in his fall.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, dressed as Iron Man and shared a photo on Instagram to celebrate the release of 'Avengers: Age of Ultron'. The post featured Haskell in an Iron Man costume with a message about releasing his inner Iron Man. Haskell has had a diverse career, playing rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand after leaving Wasps in 2009. He returned to Wasps in 2012, surpassing 100 appearances for the club and earning 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the rising trend of wide-leg trousers in Spring 2015, available in various styles such as denim, cropped, printed, or striped. The trend is seen as a refreshing alternative to skinny jeans, with celebrities like Louise Redknapp and Poppy Delevingne embracing it. The key to pulling off wide-leg trousers is to wear them with high heels and a simple top to maintain proportion. Denim is considered the easiest way to try this trend, with brands like Gucci, Topshop, and Celine showcasing their versions. The trend is versatile, suitable for both casual and dressy occasions, and can be worn regardless of the weather.

The University of Michigan decided to screen "American Sniper" despite objections from over 200 students who signed a petition against it, citing negative depictions of the Middle East. The decision was reversed after a backlash, with the university's vice president acknowledging the mistake and reinstating the movie as part of the UMix social events series. An alternative screening of "Paddington" will be offered for those uncomfortable with "American Sniper." The decision was praised by Michigan's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly set a quokka on fire with an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The animal survived but was singed. The men, aged 18 and 24, were questioned, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty. They will face court on April 17. Quokkas are found on small islands off the Western Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old dancer who performed in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar during the 1930s and 1940s, was shown early music videos of her performances by filmmakers and volunteers, as she had never seen herself dance before due to lost photographs and memorabilia. She was delighted to see her past performances.

third of men in Britain have never washed their own car, with only 12% doing so regularly, according to a study by vehicle leasing firm OSV. The decline in car washing is attributed to factors such as shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicle sizes. People are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, with 15 million cars cleaned by owners during the recent Easter break. Cars are most likely to be washed weekly in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least likely in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are most likely to wash their cars, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners are least likely. The decline in car washing is also due to the availability of automated machines and cheaper options for professional car washing services.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him and Liverpool since joining in 2008, but believes the team can overcome the challenge of replacing him. Gerrard is set to feature in the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to end his Liverpool career by making the final and beating Arsenal. Skrtel acknowledges Gerrard's importance to the club and believes there are potential replacements for him, provided they receive the right support. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool line-up after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, adding to his legendary golf career. Nicklaus was playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw when he achieved this feat on the 130-yard fourth hole. Although this was Nicklaus' first hole-in-one at Augusta, his accomplishment was overshadowed by Colombian player Camilo Villegas, who also scored an ace on the fourth hole and one on the eighth. However, Villegas lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. Nicklaus, who has won six Masters titles and is one of five men to complete the career grand slam, became the youngest person to wear a green jacket in 1963 and collected his sixth in 1986.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night due to several storms, with a tornado reported 6 miles northwest of Goddard, posing risks to nearby communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of the dangers of nighttime tornadoes. Tornado sightings were also reported in southwestern Kansas and Missouri. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, is accused of fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser, and has pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter. Despite the ongoing case, a judge allowed Bates to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, causing the Harris family to express their disappointment and perceived indifference. Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2. The defense plans to present evidence of Bates' proper law enforcement training. The case has also raised concerns about preferential treatment and potential misconduct within the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office.

Irish fighter Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. McGregor has recently revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, symbolizing his readiness for the fight. He believes he has more motivation to win the title than Aldo, who is making the eighth defense of his belt. The two have a tense relationship, highlighted by an incident in March when McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, faced criticism for glorifying binge drinking after he was seen happily skolling (drinking quickly) a beer at a university function. Critics argue that Abbott, as a leader, should discourage such behavior, not promote it. Abbott's action was seen as associating masculinity with alcohol consumption. Despite the controversy, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating there was nothing wrong with his actions. Abbott's action is not unique among Australian Prime Ministers, with former Labor Prime Minister Bob Hawke also known for his skolling skills. However, critics argue that such actions perpetuate harmful stereotypes and glorify irresponsible drinking.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary cases linked to Scott County, following the approval of a short-term needle exchange program by Governor Mike Pence. The outbreak primarily affects intravenous drug users who use the painkiller Opana. The needle exchange program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, may be extended beyond its initial 30-day period, but the future of the program and similar initiatives in other counties remains uncertain. Critics argue that the association between needle exchanges and illegal drug activity makes such programs politically uncomfortable, despite evidence of their effectiveness in reducing harm. Federal funding for needle exchange programs has been banned since 1989, and Governor Pence's executive order did not include funding for the Scott County program.

football fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take an Arsenal quiz, which she passed with 87%. He used a school exam format with instructions like "read every question twice" and "calculators may be used." Saskia scored well but had some mistakes, like confusing player positions. Her boyfriend provided feedback with corrections and an emoticon for wrong answers. Saskia humorously answered why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard, earning extra points. Her boyfriend was impressed with her overall score and decided not to break up with her. The story was shared on Twitter, where it received mixed reactions, with some finding the boyfriend's actions endearing and others considering them excessive.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an undercover DEA informant for 27 years in exchange for promised US citizenship. Toro provided crucial information leading to the prosecution of drug lord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, Toro faces deportation after retiring due to declining health, as the DEA did not assist him with his citizenship. Toro fears for his life if returned to Colombia and is currently in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits without a green card or passport.

A 14-year-old Indian girl from Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, set herself on fire after allegedly being raped by five men from her village. She is now recovering in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The incident occurred when she went outside her house to relieve herself. The accused men have been arrested. The case has sparked outrage and protests in India, highlighting the issue of sexual assault and the need for better protection for women.

anchester United Manager Louis van Gaal has expressed his desire to beat rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford, but will have to do so without Robin van Persie, who is not fit enough to play according to van Gaal. Despite this, the team is in good shape and the manager believes a win could secure a top-four finish and Champions League qualification. Van Gaal also mentioned that Luke Shaw is not yet fit to play. The manager is looking forward to the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford, as he takes on City with home advantage for the first time since arriving at the club.

In a Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium, Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes. Supporters expressed their frustration with the rising costs of attending matches, especially after the announcement of a £5.14 billion TV rights deal. The cheapest tickets for the game were £64, one of the highest prices in the league. Fans from both clubs held banners displaying their discontent, and organizers from Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups called for a reduction in ticket prices. The protest highlighted the growing discontent among football fans over the increasing commercialization of the sport.

A newborn baby, Star, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. Her parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were not suitable donors for a liver transplant. Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, who is Jade's twin sister, offered part of her liver to save her niece. The transplant was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery, although she will need regular blood tests, liver function tests, and anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life. Shanell did not hesitate to donate part of her liver to save her niece.

In the Audi Football Challenge, Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake teamed up to compete against Loic Remy and Willian. The competition consisted of three rounds, with Hazard and Ake winning the first two rounds by scoring goals from close range and over a makeshift tennis net. The final round involved shooting footballs from long range into a convertible Audi. Despite Hazard and Ake's strong performance, Remy and Willian managed to secure a victory in the last round. However, Willian accidentally damaged one of the cars during the competition.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a fatal highway crash that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger, 54, was initially charged with reckless manslaughter but pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and one count of assault. He claimed he was not suicidal during the crash, but prosecutors argued he was depressed and trying to kill himself. Dellinger's wife described him as a man of ethics and integrity. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit. Dellinger's lawyers argued that he was suffering from medication withdrawal and multiple sclerosis symptoms.

Lacey Spears, a Kentucky woman, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and frustration towards Spears on Facebook, wishing she would die in prison. Spears, who suffers from a mental illness, was accused of causing her son's repeated hospitalizations and ultimately his death to gain attention. Her lawyer argued for a minimum sentence, claiming she was a hardworking single mother who loved her son unconditionally. The prosecution argued that Spears intentionally poisoned her son, and her social media posts about his medical issues were used as evidence in the trial. Spears did not testify at her trial.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket. These strains caused a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the US, as the previous vaccine was not a good match. The updated vaccine will be available for high-risk groups, including young, old, and indigenous Australians, from April 20. Experts recommend getting the vaccine, which also protects against the H1N1 strain. The vaccine has been modified based on global circulation patterns, and it is expected to prevent more deaths than the previous version. People are advised to book their flu shots now due to a delay in stock arrival.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from National Geographic and potential budget cuts that could affect the site's management. This comes at a time when Illinois is experiencing a financial crisis and the state's historic preservation agency, which manages the tomb, may be eliminated. The tomb, which was recently criticized for its lack of historical character, has undergone significant repairs and renovations, costing over $2.5 million. Despite the criticism, many visitors find the site impressive and beautiful.

The passage discusses the resurgence of various 90s and early 2000s fashion trends, including chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, Calvin Klein logo t-shirts, and JNCO jeans. It highlights the return of bucket hats, camouflage print, designer prints, double denim, UGG boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers. The text mentions celebrities like Rihanna, Jordan Dunn, Kylie Jenner, Victoria Beckham, Britney Spears, and Kim Kardashian, who have embraced these retro styles. Some trends, like the bucket hat and camouflage print, have been revived by modern celebrities, while others, like JNCO jeans, have faced criticism for their impracticality.

The passage covers a variety of trending stories from a particular week. These include four rainbows appearing in New York after heavy rain, a crackdown on exotic dancers at wakes in rural China, Kardashian-related trends such as the #KylieJennerChallenge, a 102-year-old woman experiencing a prom-posal involving bombs, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', Johnny Depp's transformation in 'Black Mass', a unique pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombing his son's picture.

The Miami Open featured extensive celebrations for tennis players' milestones, with Serena Williams reaching her 700th career victory and Andy Murray his 500th. Williams received a cake after defeating Sabine Lisicki in the semi-finals, while Murray had a similar celebration earlier. Williams's next opponent in the finals will be Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens. Despite a setback at Wimbledon 2013 against Lisicki, Williams advanced to the semi-finals.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and owner of a second-floor cafe in Karachi, was known for promoting free speech, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. She was shot dead by two gunmen after hosting a discussion on a controversial topic. Mahmud was a prominent figure for humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan, and her death has sparked outrage and grief across the country. The discussion she led before her death was on a topic that many wanted silenced, and the event was shut down by authorities. Despite receiving death threats in the past, Mahmud continued to advocate for open dialogue and was a symbol of hope for many Pakistanis. Her cafe, also known as T2F, was a hub for secular wisdom and artistic expression.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old healer and refugee from the partition of India, has lived in Indian Kashmir for 70 years without citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote. As a Hindu from the Punjab province, he is part of the West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) who fled during the partition but have been denied rights due to the ongoing territorial dispute with Pakistan. The recent election of Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party has given hope to Ram and thousands of others that they may finally be able to shed their refugee status and enjoy the rights of citizenship. However, the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state has been a concern for successive governments, and the WPRs have been caught in the middle of this political issue. Despite the prosperity of Kashmir, the WPRs live in poverty, and their children are unable to access state-run education or employment. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has pledged to normalize the WPRs' status, but the community is prepared to take action if their

oshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering a move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have reportedly made an offer of around £4 million. Muto wants to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Chelsea plans to loan Muto to Vitesse Arnhem next season. Real Zaragoza's Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut, believes Muto has great potential and could be a good fit for Chelsea. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho has acknowledged the club's interest in Muto, but has not commented further on the player. Muto is still considering the move and wants to make the best decision for his career.

The passage congratulates Australia for abandoning the policy of excluding overseas-based players from selection, criticizing England's outdated approach. It highlights the improved performances of players like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage after moving to French clubs, arguing that player location should not dictate selection. The author urges England to select the best players available, regardless of their club affiliation, to maximize their chances of winning the World Cup. The passage praises Australia's decision and criticizes England's reluctance to follow suit.

The passage discusses the Firechat app, which enables messaging without a web or mobile signal by creating a wireless mesh network using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) or a similar Android feature. Open Garden developers have created the Greenstone device, an egg-shaped gadget that boosts these off-the-grid networks by acting as a beacon to help messages move more easily between devices within a localized network. Firechat, which has been downloaded over five million times, allows users to send messages and photos within a 200ft range, useful in situations with limited connectivity. Greenstone aims to extend this range and is still under development, currently working with Firechat at a 20ft range.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle seeks to change negative perceptions of the word 'fat' by embracing it as a body-positive self-descriptor in her TED talk. She argues that 'fat' should not be synonymous with 'ugly' and discusses the rise in size discrimination and societal pressure for women to be thin. Bustle believes that increased exposure to body diversity can lead to greater acceptance and preference for different body types. She shares her personal experience with burlesque, which she finds empowering and body-positive, and encourages others to find a 'courage reference' to boost self-esteem. Her TED talk has received mostly positive feedback and has inspired viewers to reevaluate their views on body image.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has been frequently seen on the bench during the season, only starting in 16 out of 33 Premier League games. Despite this, he participated in a photoshoot with teammates and model Olga Sherer for the fashion house Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Walcott is hoping to secure a starting position in the upcoming match against Hull, after being named on the bench for the majority of the season.

An impressive collection of props and puppets from Hollywood blockbusters, created by renowned make-up effects artist Rick Baker, will be auctioned at the end of May at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on PropStore.com. The collection, valued at an estimated $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions and features iconic pieces from films like Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas. Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, the Two-Face mask from Batman Forever, and the Grinch costume from the Jim Carrey film. The auction will also feature items from Baker's other works, such as An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, and Batman & Robin. The collection includes over 400 items, with individual pieces expected to fetch high prices.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, was tragically killed in the French Alps while skiing with his family. He became separated from his mother, ventured into dense woodland, and fell off a 164ft drop. His body was found by following his footprints in the snow. Carwyn was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster with a love for the mountains and farming. His family is devastated, and his school community is grieving his loss.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with having the perfect figure and feeling pressured to be a size zero. She restricted her food intake to one piece of fruit a day and hid food, leading to her collapse from starvation. After spending a week on a heart monitor, she received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery. Laura now advocates for positive body image and has made it to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB.

Liverpool supporters expressed their expectation for Raheem Sterling to remain with the club during a new home kit unveiling event at Anfield. The new kit, designed by New Balance, is part of a £300 million four-year deal. Sterling, along with other players, modeled the new strip, which features an all-white design and a new collar style. Despite rumors of Sterling's potential departure, Liverpool officials and fans are hopeful that he will stay. The kit also pays tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims with the number 96 and a memorial flame.

The University of Manchester researchers have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky, using data from the Dark Energy Camera. This map is the first in a series that will eventually provide a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky. The map will help astronomers study galaxy formation and test current cosmological theories. The Dark Energy Survey (DES), which aims to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, uses gravitational lensing to study the effects of dark matter on light from distant galaxies. The survey's analysis supports the idea that galaxies form in areas with high concentrations of dark matter. The map was created by analyzing 130 million telescope images of galaxies and required significant computing power to measure the shape of each galaxy with high precision. The DES will be completed by 2018.

Manchester United has officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch international. United manager Louis van Gaal is keen on making Depay one of his first signings this summer. Depay has been a key player for PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games this season. He has also represented the Netherlands in the World Cup. PSV is considering offers from other European clubs, including Paris-Saint Germain. Depay started his career at VV Moordrecht and joined PSV at the age of 12. He is considered a talented player with potential to become as good as Arjen Robben or even Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's young side in a strong performance at the academy stadium. Dominic Solanke scored a late goal, following Tammy Abraham's double that gave Chelsea the first-half lead. Tammy Abraham was a key player with two goals, while Solanke also contributed significantly. Manchester City's Tosin Adarabioyo was a solid presence in defense, and Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored for City, briefly equalizing the game. Chelsea's defense, midfield, and attack were generally dominant, with players like Charlie Colkett and Kasey Palmer making impactful appearances off the bench.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, believes that people are born with a sexual preference, but opposes same-sex marriage being a constitutional right. He thinks the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio stated he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, despite his personal disagreement. He also mentioned that states should regulate marriage and any changes should be debated politically, not by the courts. Rubio, a Catholic, believes divorce is wrong but would continue to love someone who is divorced. He has received significant financial support for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, quit their jobs to cycle around the world without a fixed plan or agenda. They have been on the road for almost a year, covering nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They live frugally, spending less than three euros a day by relying on free accommodation, their own legs for transportation, and inexpensive food. They often camp under the stars or use hospitality websites for lodging. They have been supported by the kindness of strangers, who sometimes invite them for meals or provide free produce. They have documented their journey on their blog, TheCrazyTravel. Their next destinations include Georgia, Armenia, and eventually cycling across the Pacific and the length of the American continent.

A Texas couple who got married in 2012 is suing their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premier Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on the bottom of their photo booth pictures. The couple only found out about the incident months later when the bride's sister informed them. Evans denied the allegations and suggested the couple sue him. The couple's lawyer, Cathy Hale, stated that her clients want an apology from Evans, and the case is set for trial in July if mediation fails. The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract.

Mike Brown, the England full-back, is uncertain about his return date to Harlequins after a concussion. He plans to take a cautious approach to recovery, having experienced symptoms like headaches post-game. Brown emphasizes the importance of being aware of concussion symptoms, a lesson reinforced by online modules from World Rugby. He withdrew from playing against Ireland in the Six Nations due to these symptoms. Brown also highlights the significance of not rushing back to play and encourages teammates to do the same if they show symptoms. George North has been advised not to play again this season after four concussions, and Johnny Sexton was sidelined for 12 weeks. Brown's comments are part of Land Rover's 'We Deal in Real' campaign for the Rugby World Cup 2032.

leading expert suggests that smartphone use and increased internet connectivity may be responsible for a decline in sexual frequency among couples in the UK. Research shows that couples are now having sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. The expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter, attributes this decline to the integration of public and private lives, constant email checking, and the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world. Researcher Catherine Mercer adds that competing demands on time and late-night work emails can further reduce focus on sexual activity.

The passage discusses the decline in popularity of Tibetan Mastiffs in China, which were once highly valued and could command prices of up to £1.2 million. Their fall from grace is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption campaign, which has reduced the practice of giving these expensive dogs as gifts to officials. Additionally, new regulations banning the ownership of dogs over 50 kg in several cities have negatively impacted the breed's popularity. The market collapse has led to many of these dogs being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in hotpots and their skins for leather products. The breed's decline has also been accelerated by cross-breeding for profit, resulting in a surplus of lower-quality dogs. The breed's boom began in 2005 when they were seen as status symbols, but rapid urbanization has made them less suited to city living.

A survey of 600 Parisian women revealed that all had experienced sexual harassment on public transport, with half of them being assaulted before the age of 18. The harassment ranged from insults and intimidation to sexual attacks and rape. This issue led to six out of ten women feeling unsafe on public transport, causing them to change their daily routines to avoid confrontation. The report, handed to the French Women's Rights Ministry, called for a campaign to address sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains. The council emphasized the need for women to be able to move freely without fear and for education on the issue to reach aggressors and witnesses.

A company is running a competition called #everydayfix to design products for common everyday problems. The public can vote for their favorite prototype on Twitter, and the winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. The top three everyday emergencies identified were not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. The three prototypes designed to solve these problems are Snooze, a silent alarm clock; Forget Me Lock, a key device that shows if a door is locked or unlocked; and Nipper, a portable phone charger that can be powered by any household battery. The public will vote on their favorite prototype, and the winning product will be developed further. Other prototypes that did not make the final shortlist include a helmet with bone conduction headphones for cyclists, a parking pin that alerts you when a parking space is free, and an app that allows you to nominate people to receive your messages when your phone dies.

police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under investigation for awarding £500,000 of public funds to a charity she directs, Victims First Northumbria. The charity, which supports crime victims, is run by Baird and Northumbria's Chief Constable Sue Sim. Critics argue this is a conflict of interest and have called it a'soap opera' within the force. The Ministry of Justice is probing the case to determine if any conflict of interest rules were broken. Despite the controversy, Baird insists all procedures were followed and defends the establishment of the charity. Sue Sim, who is retiring in June, has faced previous accusations of bullying.

Two others are awaiting sentencing, and one defendant is awaiting trial.
